questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right foot pain. The patient describes the pain as “burning” and located on the sole of the foot and the toes. The pain radiates to the calf and is exacerbated by prolonged standing and running. The patient has not suffered any trauma to the right foot. The patient currently runs 10 to 20 miles daily for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pain with passive dorsiflexion and eversion of the right ankle. Sensation to light touch and pressure are reduced over the plantar surface of the right foot. Tapping posterior to the right medial malleolus produces a tingling, electric shock sensation. Deep tendon reflexes are within normal limits. Compression of which of the following nerves is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a sharp, burning pain and reduced sensation over the sole of the feet and a positive Tinel sign (shock-like sensation on tapping the tibial nerve behind the medial malleolus), consistent with tarsal tunnel syndrome, secondary to the compression of tibial nerve.   

The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and traverses through the popliteal fossa and posterior compartment of the leg. It then enters the foot through the tarsal tunnel inferior and posterior to the medial malleolus where it innervates the plantar surface of the foot. Injury or compression of the tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel results in sensory loss over the sole of the foot. Plantarflexion and inversion of the foot remains intact, as fibers innervating these muscles branch proximally to the tarsal tunnel. Common risk factors for tarsal tunnel syndrome include benign tumors/cysts, bone spurs, overuse injury, inflammation of the tendon sheath or swelling from a broken or sprained ankle.  

In contrast, injury to the nerve at the popliteal fossa (e.g., deep penetrating trauma or knee surgery) results in loss of plantar flexion, loss of flexion of toes and weakened inversion. Consequently, patients often present with feet held in the calcaneovalgus position (everted at rest with loss of inversion and plantar flexion).  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve can be compressed during prolonged maintenance in the dorsal lithotomy position or from pelvic fractures or hip dislocations. Patients present with sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, weakness of knee flexion and hip extension, and decreased patellar reflexes. A positive Tinel sign posterior to the medial malleolus is suggestive of tarsal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Common peroneal:
Incorrect: Compression of the common peroneal nerve occurs at the proximal fibula due to prolonged hyperflexion of the knee or from leg casting. Sensory symptoms occur at the posterolateral leg and dorsolateral foot and are often associated with foot drop.   
✅ Tibial:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ilioinguinal :
Incorrect: The Ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the upper medial thigh and perineum. Injury to this nerve can occur during pelvic surgery, and presents with chronic suprapubic or groin pain. The ilioinguinal nerve does not innervate the sole of the foot.  
❌ Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve results in decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Women who wear tight clothes are especially predisposed to impingement of this nerve. A positive Tinel sign, posterior to the medial malleolus, is suggestive of tibial nerve compression.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after injuring his left knee in a bicycle accident. Physical examination shows significant knee swelling with abrasions of the overlying skin. Distal motor and sensory function are intact. No other signs of trauma are present. X-ray of the left knee reveals a nondisplaced patellar fracture. The patient is subsequently referred to an orthopedic surgeon and placed in a leg cast. On a follow-up visit one week later, the patient endorses difficulty moving his left foot. Physical examination demonstrates limited dorsiflexion and eversion of the left foot, as well as limited extension of the left toes. Deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. The remainder of the examination of the left and right lower extremity are within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the medial surface of leg
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot
Loss of sensation over the sole of the foot
Decreased sensation over the medial thigh
Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh

questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of eversion and dorsiflexion of the foot, following placement of a leg cast, consistent with common peroneal nerve compression at the femoral neck.   

The common fibular nerve serves as a terminal branch of the sciatic nerve and arises proximal to the popliteal fossa. From here, it courses laterally around the head and neck of the fibula and divides into:  

  • Superficial branches: foot eversion (lateral compartment of leg) and sensory innervation of dorsum of foot (except webspace between hallux and 2nd digit). 
  • Deep branches: dorsiflexion (anterior compartment of foot and leg) and sensory innervation of the webspace between hallux and 2nd digit. 
 The nerve is susceptible to injury (e.g., fibular neck fractures and tightly applied plaster cast) due to its superficial location at the neck of the fibula. Patient’s with injury at this location typically present with foot drop (difficulty dorsiflexing the foot against resistance or gravity), eversion and paresthesias, and/or sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot, lateral shin, and between first and second toes. Gait examination often shows a “steppage gait,” where the knees raise higher than normal with each step due to the weakness of foot dorsiflexion.  



Option Analysis

❌ Loss of sensation over the medial surface of leg:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation on the medial surface of leg results from the saphenous nerve injury.  
✅ Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of sensation over the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation on the sole of the foot is characteristic of tibial nerve compression in the tarsal tunnel. The common fibular nerve does not innervate the plantar surface of the foot.  
❌ Decreased sensation over the medial thigh:
Incorrect: The obturator nerve is responsible for the medial thigh sensation. Its injury can result from surgeries of the pelvis (e.g. hysterectomy).  
❌ Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh:
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve can result in decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Women who wear tight clothes are predisposed to this injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right heel pain. He was playing tennis with his son when he experienced a sharp, stabbing pain of his right heel with an associated “popping” sound. The patient has been unable to ambulate since the injury occurred. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus which is adequately managed with metformin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a palpable gap two centimeters proximal to the right heel. The right leg does not yield plantar flexion with squeezing of the calf. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of sudden onset sharp heel pain, inability to bear-weight, positive Thompson test (absence of plantarflexion when squeezing the gastrocnemius muscle), and a palpable gap is consistent with Achilles tendon rupture.    

The soleus and the gastrocnemius muscles converge to form the Achilles tendon, which inserts posteriorly on the calcaneus. Rupture of this tendon usually occurs while performing actions requiring sudden changes in acceleration, such as pushing off, jumping, or changing direction while running. Most cases occur in male patients aged 30–40 years old, with associated risk factors of obesity, fluoroquinolone use, or systemic corticosteroid use. Patients typically present with a sharp pain and an inability to bear weight, in cases of a complete rupture. Physical examination may show a swollen heel, a palpable defect in the Achilles tendon two to six centimeters proximal to the calcaneus, an inability to stand on toes, and a positive squeeze test (Thompson test).   

Achilles tendon rupture may be diagnosed solely by clinical examination, but a bedside ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis. All complete tendon ruptures require surgical consultation.  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction:
Incorrect: Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction is caused by chronic overuse injury of the tendon, impairing its ability to support the arch of the foot. Patients typically develop swelling and tenderness along the course of the tendon, accompanied by weakness with foot inversion. A positive squeeze test is suggestive of achilles tendon rupture.  
❌ Ankle sprain:
Incorrect: Ankle sprains present with pain and swelling about the ankle joint, not heel, as seen in this patient. Moreover, a palpable gap directly proximal to the heel and a positive squeeze test is highly sensitive for achilles tendon rupture.  
✅ Achilles tendon rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcaneal stress fracture:
Incorrect: A calcaneal stress fracture can result from repetitive stress to the foot. Patients present with generalized pain in the heel that develops over several days to weeks. The pain usually increases with activity and improves with rest. Sudden sharp heel pain with a palpable posterior heel defect is suggestive of achilles tendon rupture.  
❌ Calcaneal apophysitis:
Incorrect: Calcaneal apophysitis refers to inflammation of the heel’s growth plate. This injury pattern results from repetitive microtrauma due to strain on the Achilles tendon at the apophysis. Patients often present with heel pain that worsens while running or jumping. This patient has a positive Thompson test, suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of inability to bear weight on her right leg. The patient fell onto her right hip after a trip over the curb a few hours ago. Past medical history is significant for osteoporosis and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates shortening of the right leg with associated external rotation. There is swelling and bruising around the right lateral hip and limited range of motion at the right hip joint. The patient has a 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the right lower extremity. A right hip joint X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Posterior dislocation of the femoral head

questions.solution:
This patient’s radiograph, mechanism of injury, and exam findings are consistent with a femoral neck fracture–one of the most common hip fracture patterns. Femoral neck fractures are common in older patients, especially those with underlying osteoporosis. They can occur with low energy falls and have a high morbidity and mortality rate.  

Hip fractures get divided into intracapsular (femoral head and neck) or extracapsular (intertrochanteric or subtrochanteric). Specifically, a femoral neck or head fracture is an intracapsular, displaced fracture that typically occurs following a fall onto the lateral hip. Patients with a displaced femoral neck fracture are generally unable to bear weight on the affected side and present with a shortened leg with external rotation of the affected hip (due to the psoas and iliacus muscle contraction without acetabular counterforce). Notably, intracapsular fractures can be associated with disruption of the blood supply from the medial circumflex artery, resulting in avascular necrosis. Femoral head fractures are often associated with posterior dislocation of the hip and are at increased risk of sciatic nerve injury. Because of the potential for avascular necrosis with intracapsular fractures arthroplasty with hip replacement is typically the procedure of choice.  

In contrast, an intertrochanteric fracture is an extracapsular fracture that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanters. A subtrochanteric fracture which is defined as a fracture within 5 cm distal to the lesser trochanter is also considered an extracapsular fracture. Clinical presentation is similar to femoral neck fractures. Both fracture patterns require surgical correction (e.g. open reduction with internal fixation) unless the patient is not a good surgical candidate. With extracapsular fractures the blood supply is usually intact and fixation is the procedure of choice.  



Option Analysis

❌ Posterior dislocation of the femoral head:
Incorrect: Posterior dislocation of the femoral head occurs secondary to high-velocity motor vehicle collisions. Clinical examination often reveals a shortened, adducted, and internally rotated lower extremity with the hip and knee held in flexion. This patient has radiographic evidence of a femoral neck fracture.
❌ Greater trochanter fracture:
Incorrect: A fracture of the greater trochanter can result from forceful contraction of the hip abductors with a fall onto the lateral hip. It presents with an exacerbation of hip pain with abduction and localized tenderness over the greater trochanter. This patient has radiographic evidence of a femoral neck fracture.
✅ Femoral neck fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Greater trochanteric pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) results from gluteus medius and minimus tendinopathy. It presents with chronic lateral hip pain worse with repetitive hip flexion or direct pressure. Physical examination demonstrates point tenderness over the greater trochanter. Radiographs are usually unremarkable.
❌ Intertrochanteric fracture:
Incorrect: Intertrochanteric fractures present with hip pain, swelling, and ecchymosis. Physical examination demonstrates local tenderness over the trochanteric area and an externally rotated and shortened extremity. Radiography shows cortical discontinuity between the two trochanters. This patient’s radiograph demonstrates a femoral neck fracture.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient is currently experiencing severe right hip pain. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an alert man, oriented to time and place. The patient is lying on his left side with an internally rotated and shortened right leg with a large hematoma at the lateral right hip. The right hip is held in a flexed and adducted position. An x-ray of the pelvis and hip is shown below. A detailed neurologic examination will likely reveal which of the following findings?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Decreased sensation over the medial thigh
Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh
Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a posterior hip dislocation following high-velocity trauma. Motor vehicle collisions (knee-to-dashboard) are the most common mechanism for this type of injury. Clinical examination often reveals a slightly shortened extremity with adduction and internal rotation of the hip with the knee held in flexion.    

Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the pelvis and hip identify posterior dislocations. The sciatic nerve is especially vulnerable to injury as it traverses the posterior aspect of the hip joint. Injury can result in weakness of knee flexion (sciatic nerve), ankle dorsiflexion (common fibular nerve), and decreased ankle reflex (tibial nerve), as well as decreased sensation in the distribution of the affected nerve (e.g. dorsum of the foot).   

Other associated complications of posterior dislocation of the hip include avascular necrosis of the femoral head (due to compromised blood supply), femoral head or acetabular fracture, and tear of the labrum.  



Option Analysis

❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve helps form the cremasteric reflex pathway. Injury to this nerve can result from laparoscopic surgery; however, posterior hip dislocation is not associated with genitofemoral nerve injury. 
❌ Decreased sensation over the medial thigh:
Incorrect: The obturator nerve is responsible for medial thigh sensation. Injury to this nerve often results from surgeries of the pelvis (e.g. hysterectomy). A posterior hip dislocation does not affect this nerve.
❌ Decreased sensation over the anterior and lateral thigh:
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve can decrease anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Posterior hip dislocations do not affect this nerve.
✅ Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased patellar reflex:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve is involved in the motor pathway of the patellar reflex, and it can be injured  from pelvic fractures. This patient’s radiograph suggests a right posterior hip dislocation without evidence of pelvic fracture.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of left thigh pain and numbness. The patient’s symptoms started two days after a 12-hour tech rehearsal for a Shakespearen play. She was wearing her costume, which includes a corset, and noticed numbness and burning sensation over the lateral side of her left thigh following the rehearsal. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates loss of light touch and pinprick sensation over the upper lateral thigh. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and deep tendon reflexes are +2. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. Pain is reproduced with tapping immediately below the anterior superior iliac spine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is a mononeuropathy resulting from the compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) which travels from the lumbar plexus, through the abdominal cavity, under the inguinal ligament, and into the subcutaneous tissue of the thigh. Commonly identified risk factors include pregnancy, tight-fitted clothes/seat belts, obesity, and diabetes mellitus. Affected patients present with pain, paresthesias (numbness and tingling), and hypoesthesia (diminished sensation) over the upper outer thigh. Muscle strength, however, is normal as the LFCN does not carry motor fibers. Symptoms may be reproduced with tapping over the lateral aspect of the inguinal ligament (Tinel's sign).    

Diagnosis is clinical, and most patients are managed with weight loss and avoidance of exacerbating factors (e.g. avoiding tight-fitted clothing). Anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin, or gabapentin) can help reduce neuropathic pain in patients with refractory symptoms.   

Option Analysis

❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh, inguinal region, and lower abdomen. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. 
✅ Wearing tight fitting clothes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents as dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh is suggestive of cutaneous nerve compression injury.
❌ Femoral neuropathy:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve innervates the anteromedial skin of the thigh (via the medial femoral cutaneous branch) as well as medial lower leg via the saphenous nerve. Femoral neuropathy is associated with diminished or absent knee jerk reflexes. 
❌ Increased intracompartmental pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracompartmental pressure occurs in patients with acute compartment syndrome, which more commonly develops following a severe injury–such as a car accident or long bone fracture. It typically causes severe pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the affected limb.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of foot pain. She started hiking recently to lose some weight. The patient reports dull, achy pain at the left medial ankle. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates pain with palpation posterior to the medial malleolus. Upon weight bearing and gait analysis, the physician notes a collapse of the medial longitudinal arch, outward tilted heels, valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction, as shown below. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is a common etiology of this patient’s presentation? 
 

Image obtained from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with foot pain during increased activity and collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing, suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction (PTTD). Over time, this condition results in an acquired flat foot (pes planus). 

Flatfoot is a progressive deformity characterized by the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with forefoot abduction and hindfoot valgus. The most common etiology of acquired flatfoot is PTTD. Other causes include congenital ligamentous laxity (e.g., Marfan syndrome and pregnancy), degenerative or inflammatory arthropathies, and rheumatoid arthritis. 

Flatfoot may or may not be symptomatic. Patients may endorse dull, achy arch pain, medial ankle or heel pain, and a sensation of “muscle weakness” or fatigue with exercise. Physical examination demonstrates collapse of the medial longitudinal arch with weight bearing, the ‘too many toes’ sign (examiner can see all four toes when looking at the foot from behind), valgus hindfoot deformity, and forefoot abduction.       

Option Analysis

❌ Plantar aponeurosis inflammation :
Incorrect: Plantar fasciitis results from inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, secondary to chronic overuse and repetitive trauma at its insertion site. Patients typically present with sharp and stabbing heel pain that is worse when walking and with tenderness at the insertion point of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
✅ Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neuropathic Charcot changes :
Incorrect: Charcot joint presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma and impaired proprioception and sensation of pain. Collapse of the medial longitudinal arch on weight-bearing is suggestive of posterior tibial tendon dysfunction.  
❌ Fibularis tendon tendinopathy :
Incorrect: Patients with fibularis tendon tendinopathy present with pain, and occasionally, swelling and warmth of the posterolateral aspect of the ankle. 
❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint sprain :
Incorrect: First metatarsophalangeal joint sprains result from an injury to the big toe secondary to forced hyperextension. This patient does not have evidence of an isolated digit injury.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with COPD is undergoing repair of a torn shoulder labrum. The patient develops tachypnea and respiratory distress as the orthopedic surgeon prepares for surgery. While in the preoperative suit, the anesthesiologist performs an interscalene nerve block. Vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 26/minute,  pulse is 109/minute, blood pressure is 101/67 mmHg, and SPO<sub>2</sub> is 81% on 2L nasal cannula.  Physical examination demonstrates a frail man with increased work of breathing and faint end-expiratory wheezing. The patient subsequently undergoes rapid sequence intubation with the demonstration of bilateral breath sounds following endotracheal tube placement. Which anatomic structures were most likely implicated in this patient’s abrupt change in respiratory status?
questions.solution:
An interscalene nerve block anesthetizes most of the territory innervated by the brachial plexus and is generally performed on patients undergoing shoulder, upper arm, or elbow surgery.  Landmarks used to perform this procedure include the interscalene groove, which is found between the middle and anterior scalene muscles at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra, which is approximately at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Nerves anesthetized during this procedure include most of the brachial plexus, sparing the ulnar (C8-T1) nerve.  In addition, the phrenic nerve is often anesthetized during this procedure, resulting in ipsilateral hemidiaphragmatic paralysis. Therefore, patients with underlying respiratory conditions (e.g. COPD) should not undergo this procedure. In addition, the recurrent laryngeal nerve is often anesthetized--resulting in temporary paralysis of the ipsilateral vocal fold. Additional complications include iatrogenic pneumothorax, as well as hematoma/seroma formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phrenic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Visceral pleura:
Incorrect: A pneumothorax may occur secondary to an interscalene nerve block; however, this patient is noted to have bilateral breath sounds following intubation.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve and digestive issues and slowed heart rate.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Spinal accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Injury manifests with shoulder/neck pain and a drooping shoulder, and weakness with overhead abduction.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right elbow pain. He is bracing himself and making sure not to move his arm at the elbow. The patient tripped while running and fell onto his outstretched right arm, holding his elbow in hyper-extension. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling and tenderness at the right elbow with a limited range of motion. X-ray of the right elbow shows a supracondylar fracture with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. Based on this fracture pattern, which of the following actions is likely to be compromised?

choices.text: Adduction of the third and fourth digits

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supracondylar fracture and postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus. This injury pattern is commonly associated with median nerve injury. Thus, the patient will most likely present with impaired thumb opposition due to thenar eminence paralysis   

Supracondylar fractures are the most common type of elbow fracture in pediatric patients. An extension-type supracondylar fracture (most common) is caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow hyperextended. The median nerve and brachial artery run anteromedially over the elbow and are most often injured with postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus .    

In contrast, the radial nerve runs anterolaterally over the elbow. It is more commonly injured when the distal humerus is displaced postero-medially. This injury can lead to inability to extend at the wrist and hand.  



Option Analysis

✅ Thumb opposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adduction of the third and fourth digits:
Incorrect: Adduction of the third and fourth digits is controlled by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. This patient has postero-lateral displacement of the distal humerus which will most likely lead to medial nerve injury which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured in cases of postero-medial displacement of the distal fragment of the humerus. This patient has postero-lateral displacement with subsequent injury to the median nerve which will affect thumb opposition.  
❌ Sensation over the posterior forearm:
Incorrect: Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand occurs in patients with radial nerve injury. This nerve can be injured with postero-medial displacement of the distal humerus not with postero-lateral displacement as seen in this case.  
❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators at the elbow are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can be injured in patients with upper nerve trunk compression.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right elbow pain. The patient reports hearing a sudden "pop" in his right elbow immediately after falling to the ground with an outstretched hand. Past medical and surgical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates ecchymosis and pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle. He has full range of motion of the shoulders bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric bilaterally. A plain radiograph of the right elbow is shown below. Based on this patient’s injury pattern, he will most likely have weakness with which of the following actions?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia

choices.text: Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a medial epicondyle avulsion fracture, which can  injure the ulnar nerve as it passes posterior to the medial aspect of the elbow. Fractures of the medial epicondyle tend to occur in children between the ages of 10 and 14 following injuries involving falling on an outstretched hand, repeated valgus stresses such as throwing a baseball, or via a direct blow. Medial epicondyle avulsion fractures can also be associated with elbow dislocations. Patients present with swelling and tenderness over the medial elbow and pain exacerbated with supination and flexion of the forearm, wrist, and digits.    

The ulnar nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus (C8-T1). It is commonly injured at the elbow from cubital tunnel syndrome, fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus, or fractures of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (causing cubitus valgus with tardy ulnar nerve palsy). Patients typically present with discomfort and loss of sensation/paraesthesias over the fourth and fifth fingers, weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger abduction/adduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits. Together, these findings are referred to as a “claw deformity.”   

Option Analysis

❌ Supination of the forearm:
Incorrect: The forearm supinators are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, which can become injured from upper nerve trunk compression. Injury to this nerve is not commonly observed in patients with medial epicondyle avulsions.  
❌ Thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Thumb opposition can become impaired in patients with underlying median nerve injury secondary to a supracondylar fracture of the humerus and lack of innervation to the thenar muscle.   
✅ Flexion of the fourth and fifth digits:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wrist extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions controlled by the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can become damaged with supracondylar or midshaft humerus fractures. Weakness of wrist extension and a wrist drop can be seen with injury to the radial nerve.  
❌ Shoulder abduction:
Incorrect: Impaired shoulder abduction occurs with axillary nerve injury secondary to shoulder dislocation or proximal humerus fracture.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up appointment after having a recent right total hip arthroplasty due to long-standing osteoarthritis. His postoperative course was unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Vitals are within normal limits. With standing the patient is able to comfortably bear weight on each leg. He leans towards his right side with ambulation. The patient’s left pelvis tilts downwards when asked to stand on the right leg. The surgical site over the lateral hip appears to be healing well, and there are no signs of infection. Hip range of motion does not cause pain and is as expected at this post-operative stage. The remainder of his physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the hip joint

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness from injury to the superior gluteal nerve. The superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1) can be injured in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty where the gluteus medius is split and retracted.  

The superior gluteal nerve is responsible for innervating the gluteus medius and maximus which abduct the thigh when a person is standing on one foot or during normal ambulation. Weakness of these muscles results in sagging of the pelvis to the unaffected side while standing on the affected leg (positive Trendelenburg sign). When ambulating, the patient will lean toward the affected side to compensate for the hip drop (gluteus medius march).



Common causes of Trendelenburg gait include superior gluteal nerve injury, tendinitis or penetrating injury of the lateral glutei, greater trochanteric avulsion, or fracture of the femoral neck.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior gluteal nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adductor muscle strain:
Incorrect: Adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction. This patient has evidence of a Trendelenburg gait and abductor weakness suggestive of superior gluteal nerve injury.  
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect:  Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis muscle spasms and irritates or compresses the sciatic nerve. Hip flexion, external rotation, or passive internal rotation exacerbate pain. A Trendelenburg gait suggests gluteus muscle weakness.
❌ Septic arthritis of the hip joint:
Incorrect: This condition presents severe joint pain (especially with range of motion), erythema, warmth, and tenderness over the affected joint. Patients are almost always unable to bear weight. A Trendelenburg gait suggests an alternative etiology.
❌ Compression of the ilioinguinal nerve:
Incorrect: The ilioinguinal nerve innervates the medial thigh and inguinal region. Compression or injury of this nerve can occur during pelvic or hernia surgery. A Trendelenburg gait results from superior gluteal nerve injury and abductor weakness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right buttock pain for three months. The patient describes the pain as dull with intermittent radiation to the right thigh and leg. The pain increases with prolonged sitting. He is currently training for a marathon that requires downhill running. The patient does not have back pain, bowel or bladder symptoms, or trauma history. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation of the right buttock. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Straight leg raise is positive on the right lower extremity. Forceful internal rotation at the hip with the thigh extended reproduces the pain. Plain radiographs and an MRI of the spine and pelvis are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an insidious onset of unilateral buttock pain that radiates to the thigh and leg, aggravated by prolonged sitting. This, in combination with a positive Freibergs test (reproduction of pain with forceful internal rotation of the hip with the thigh extended), is suggestive of Piriformis syndrome.   

Piriformis syndrome refers to a musculoskeletal condition that results from compression of the sciatic nerve as it passes through the piriformis. Compression can result from shortening, hypertrophy, or spasm of the piriformis muscle secondary to trauma or overuse. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that traverses the back of the thigh, calf, and foot. Pain from piriformis syndrome is often worse when walking upstairs, after sitting, or while walking or running. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness in the sciatic notch and often with direct palpation over the piriformis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar spinal stenosis:
Incorrect: Lumbar spinal stenosis presents with neurogenic claudication (i.e. buttock and leg pain, discomfort, sensory loss, and weakness with walking, standing, or maintaining certain postures). This patient’s unilateral buttock pain exacerbated with sitting and tenderness to palpation at the buttocks is consistent with piriformis syndrome.
❌ L1 radiculopathy:
Incorrect: L1 radiculopathy results from intervertebral disc herniation at the L1 level. Symptoms involve pain, paresthesias, sensory loss in the inguinal region, and slight weakness with hip flexion. Unilateral buttock pain with a positive Freibergs test is suggestive of piriformis syndrome.
✅ Piriformis syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Femoroacetabular impingement:
Incorrect: Femoroacetabular impingement syndrome can result from abnormal contact between the anterior femoral head and the acetabular rim. Patients present with insidious onset of groin pain that worsens with activity. Symptoms are most noticeable after sitting with hips flexed to 90 degrees for a  prolonged period (e.g a plane ride). Buttock pain is less common, and plain radiographs can often identify the impingement.
❌ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Incorrect: Iliotibial band (ITB) syndrome refers to an overuse injury of the lateral knee that occurs primarily in runners. Patients describe the insidious onset of pain localized to the lateral femoral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for right knee pain and swelling. The patient participated in a soccer match when she jumped and landed on her right foot with her right knee partially flexed. She subsequently heard a “pop” and developed swelling around her knee. Past medical history is significant for recent urinary tract infections treated with ciprofloxacin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a large effusion over the right knee. The patient is unable to bear weight or extend the knee. X-ray of the knee shows a large effusion with a low-lying patella. Which of the following additional findings will likely be seen on physical examination?

choices.text: Anterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur
Palpable defect superior to the patella
Palpable defect inferior to the patella
Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur

questions.solution:
This patient presents with limited knee extension and an inability to bear weight following a sudden forceful contraction of the quadriceps while landing on a partially flexed knee. This, combined with a low-lying patella seen on radiograph, suggests a quadriceps tendon tear (proximal to the patella in the rectus femoris tendon).  

Quadricep tendon tears usually occur in athletes following a sudden, strong contraction of the quadriceps muscles, such as when landing from a high jump or making a sudden change in direction at high speed. Patients often experience an audible pop followed by a sharp pain at the knee, rapid swelling, and limited knee extension. There is often a palpable defect above the patella indicative of the quadriceps tendon tearing from the superior portion of the patella. Risk factors for this injury pattern include chronic kidney disease and fluoroquinolone or anabolic steroid use. Diagnosis and extent of the injury can be assessed on MRI. Initial management consists of rest, ice, compression, elevation (RICE therapy), analgesics, non-weight bearing, and prompt orthopedic referral. Patients should be placed in a knee immobilizer to minimize repeated flexion at the knee.

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur:
Incorrect: Forward movement of the tibia against a fixed femur is seen with an anterior cruciate ligament tear. Knee extension is generally preserved in patients with this condition. Sudden pivoting or twisting maneuvers are typically the cause of anterior cruciate ligament tears.
✅ Palpable defect superior to the patella:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Palpable defect inferior to the patella:
Incorrect: A palpable defect below the patella suggests patellar tendon rupture. Radiographs in these patients will demonstrate a high riding patella. 
❌ Posterior knee and calf swelling:
Incorrect: Swelling in the posterior knee and calf suggests popliteal cyst rupture. It commonly affects patients with pre-existing knee pathology (e.g. osteoarthritis). 
❌ Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur:
Incorrect: Posterior translation of the tibia against a fixed femur is seen in patients with posterior cruciate ligament tears. This condition commonly results from hyperextension or an anterior blow to the proximal tibia with the knee flexed. A low riding patella seen here is suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with left shoulder pain. The pain started insidiously two weeks ago and tends to be worse at night. She has also experienced decreased range of motion in the left shoulder. The patient did not sustain any recent injuries. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient demonstrates limited active and passive range of motion, with associated pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with insidious subacute left shoulder pain with global stiffness, as well as limited active and passive range of motion. The shoulder radiograph is unremarkable. Together, these findings suggest adhesive capsulitis (also termed frozen shoulder syndrome).

Adhesive capsulitis is a poorly understood condition that results in global stiffness and pain of the glenohumeral joint. Current research postulates the condition results from spontaneous inflammation of the joint capsule, followed by the development of adhesions and fibrosis of the synovial lining. Clinically, patients present with subacute symptoms including deep, nagging shoulder pain and associated limitations in passive and active range of motion (particularly external rotation and abduction). The condition is often idiopathic but has been associated with a history of shoulder injury, diabetes, dyslipidemia, Parkinson disease, immobilization, and antiretroviral therapy.

The disease progresses through three distinct phases. First, patients experience an acute phase characterized by severe disabling shoulder pain that worsens at night, with some associated stiffness. This phase lasts 2-9 months. Next, an intermediate phase occurs wherein pain decreases but stiffness and severe loss of shoulder motion ensues. This phase lasts 4-12 months. Finally, a recovery phase occurs, wherein patients regain shoulder mobility.

Diagnosis of adhesive capsulitis is primarily clinical, as imaging findings are generally noncontributory, and radiographs are often normal. Since most cases are self-limited, management is conservative and involves a combination of rest, analgesia, and physical therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: Glenohumeral osteoarthritis more commonly occurs in older adults with a prior history of shoulder surgery or trauma. In addition, this condition presents chronically, developing over the course of months to years. Radiographic findings of glenohumeral osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and can present similarly to adhesive capsulitis. However, patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common form of shoulder dislocation. Patients with anterior shoulder dislocation will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Humeral head fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a fracture pattern on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right elbow pain for several weeks. The pain has limited his productivity at work as a plumber and worsens with extensor movements such as swinging his hammer. He has tried ibuprofen and over-the-counter pain medications with minimal pain relief. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination the patient has full range of motion of the elbow. There is tenderness to palpation at the lateral epicondyle, and pain is elicited at the right lateral elbow with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. There is no swelling, warmth, or redness over the right elbow joint. Examination of the distal forearm, wrist, and hand is noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm
Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm
Degenerative joint changes at the elbow

questions.solution:
This patient’s elbow pain is reproduced with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. This, in combination with tenderness over the lateral epicondyle, suggests a diagnosis of lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) due to overuse of the forearm extensor muscles (extensor carpi radialis brevis and extensor digitorum communis). Overuse leads to noninflammatory angiofibroblastic tendinosis at the common extensor origin of the lateral epicondyle. This condition is typically seen with repetitive wrist extension activities (such as a backhand stroke in tennis).    

In contrast, pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion suggests medial epicondylitis. Overuse of the wrist and hand flexors and forearm pronators can lead to medial epicondylitis. If left untreated, patients may develop ulnar neuropathy, given the proximity of the ulnar nerve to the medial epicondyle. Treatment options for both conditions include a combination of rest, anti-inflammatory medications, bracing, and physical therapy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of the olecranon bursa:
Incorrect: Olecranon bursitis occurs secondary to repetitive pressure or friction over the elbow joint. Patients present with posterior elbow pain and swelling of the bursa.  
❌ Radial nerve entrapment:
Incorrect: The most frequent site of radial nerve entrapment lies in the proximal forearm over the supinator and posterior interosseous branch at the radial tunnel. It can lead to numbness and decreased sensation in the hand and weakness in the hand and wrist. 
✅ Overuse of extensor muscles of the forearm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm:
Incorrect: Overuse of flexor muscles of the forearm can result in medial epicondylitis, which presents with tenderness over the medial epicondyle.   
❌ Degenerative joint changes at the elbow:
Incorrect: Degenerative joint disease of the humeroulnar joint is uncommon but can present following an injury. Patients present with chronic pain, limited range of motion, and crepitus with flexion and extension at the elbow. This patient has full range of motion at the elbow joint.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right-hand weakness. He works as a mechanic, which involves frequent screwdriver use. He does not report any trauma to his hand. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates weakness with extension of the thumb and fingers of the right hand. There is no weakness with adduction and abduction of the fingers. The patient reports mild pain with resisted middle finger extension. The sensation is intact and reflexes are +2 and symmetrical bilaterally. This patient most likely has an injury to a nerve that courses through which of the following structures?

choices.text: Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles
Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus
Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle
Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with a radial nerve (deep branch) injury as it passes through the supinator muscle–likely due to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). The radial nerve enters the forearm anterior to the lateral epicondyle, where it branches into terminal superficial and deep branches. The deep branch pierces the two heads of the supinator, where it becomes the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) and innervates the posterior compartment of the forearm. This nerve provides motor control to the wrist and finger extensors but does not provide cutaneous sensory innervation.    

Injury to the deep branch of the radial nerve at the supinator muscle often results from repetitive pronation/supination, direct trauma, or dislocation of the head of the radius. Patients usually present with finger and thumb extension weakness from loss of the extensor digitorum communis, extensor indicis proprius, and extensor digiti quinti function. Patients with this injury pattern will have preservation of cutaneous sensory function.   



Option Analysis

❌ Biceps and coracobrachialis muscles:
Incorrect: The musculocutaneous nerve courses through the biceps and coracobrachialis muscles. Injury to this nerve at that level can result from shoulder dislocation or humeral fracture and presents with sensory loss over the lateral forearm and loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees).   
❌ Flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses between the flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus muscles after traversing through the cubital tunnel at the elbow. Injury to this nerve would result in loss of flexion of the hand and digits rather than loss of extension.  
❌ Olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve courses through the olecranon and medial epicondyle of the humerus (i.e. cubital tunnel) before passing into the forearm. Compression of this nerve will result in weakness of the hand/digits with abduction and adduction and loss of sensation or paresthesias in the ulnar half of the palm and dorsum of the hand over the fourth and fifth digits on both the palmar and dorsal aspects of the hand.  
✅ Superficial and deep portions of the supinator muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres muscle:
Incorrect: Compression of the median nerve as it courses between the humeral and ulnar heads of the pronator teres muscle presents with diminished sensation in the lateral thenar eminence and the palmar aspect of the first 3 1⁄2 digits.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for left elbow pain and swelling. The patient is an air conditioning technician, which requires him to move through tight spaces while resting on his knees and elbows. He did not sustain any recent trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Upper arm exam is noncontributory. The patient has swelling at the posterior aspect of the left elbow as shown below. He has full range of motion of the elbow. He reports improvement in pain with full elbow extension and worsening with flexion. The swollen area is mildly tender to touch but is not warm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with posterior elbow swelling and tenderness consistent with olecranon bursitis. The olecranon bursa is a superficial bursa that overlies the triceps tendon and olecranon. Normally, the olecranon bursa is flat, but it can swell when it is irritated or inflamed due to direct trauma, prolonged pressure, or friction (leaning on the elbow or as part of an occupation such as laying carpet). As the bursa does not directly involve the joint, flexion/extension does not typically cause pain. Although if significantly swelling or inflammation is present, patients may experience increased pain with stretching of the bursa with flexion at the elbow.  

In addition to direct trauma, friction, and pressure, olecranon bursitis can be caused by septic bursitis or by underlying inflammatory conditions of the joint space (e.g. gout or osteoarthritis). If these are a concern, a bursal aspiration and analysis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Triceps tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Triceps tendinopathy results from repetitive elbow extension against resistance. Patients typically report pain at the posterior elbow with resisted elbow extension and tenderness at the triceps insertion at the olecranon. Swelling at the elbow would not be consistent with triceps tendinopathy.   
❌ Distal biceps tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture presents following forceful lifting with sudden pain deep in the antecubital fossa. Physical examination often reveals tenderness over the radial tubercle and pain aggravated with resisted flexion and supination of the forearm. There can be swelling at the anterior elbow and a bulge can be seen or palpated at the upper arm which is the recoiled biceps muscle. However, posterior elbow swelling is not seen and is suggestive of olecranon bursitis.  
❌ Medial epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Medial epicondylitis (i.e. golfer’s elbow) is caused by overuse of the wrist, hand flexors, and forearm pronators. Patients typically present with pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion. Posterior elbow swelling would not be expected.  
❌ Lateral epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondylitis (i.e. tennis elbow) is characterized by overuse of wrist extensors. It presents tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. It does not present with posterior elbow swelling.  
✅ Olecranon bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of a “gritty” sensation in the eyes for the last several months. She states her eyes have also been increasingly itchy and red, and she also needs to chew food for a longer period of time in order to swallow it properly. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis that is well managed with methotrexate. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness of both eyes. Bilateral wrist and first metacarpophalangeal joints show mild swelling and tenderness. There is nontender, diffuse parotid gland enlargement bilaterally. Oral examination reveals mucosal atrophy and multiple dental caries. Ophthalmologic examination reveals decreased visual acuity in both eyes. A strip of litmus filter paper is folded at one end and inserted in the patient's lower eyelid; after 5 minutes, there is < 5 mm (normal > 15 mm) of moisture on the filter paper. Multiple corneal punctate spots are noted on fluorescein staining. Labial salivary gland biopsy would most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Numerous tightly aggregated clusters of lymphocytes with interstitial fibrosis and glandular atrophy
Acinar atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and ductal dilatation with no lymphocytic infiltrates
Well-differentiated lesions with prominent keratinization and “pearl-like” structures invading the basement membrane
Mixed cellular constitution with myoepithelial cells and chondroid tissue
Uniform hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the acinar parenchyma of salivary glands
Uncontrolled proliferation of monoclonal B-cells surrounding the ducts

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with sicca symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes), abnormal Schirmer test (wherein litmus paper is used to evaluate for decreased lacrimal gland function), and corneal damage on fluorescein staining. She most likely has Sjogren syndrome.  

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by chronic inflammation of the exocrine glands. Work-up will involve checking for autoantibodies, such as anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La antibodies. In addition, a Schirmer test and fundoscopic examination with fluorescein staining can be performed to evaluate for lacrimal gland function and corneal injury, respectively.  

Labial salivary gland biopsy, while not necessary for diagnosis, is useful for confirmation. Biopsy would show focal (nodular) lymphocytic infiltrates resulting in glandular atrophy and subsequent decreased salivary and lacrimal gland function. Treatment is generally symptomatic, involving secretagogues (e.g. muscarinic agonists) to increase saliva and tear production. Moderate to severe cases involving other organs (e.g., interstitial lung disease, interstitial nephritis) require systemic glucocorticoids or disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Numerous tightly aggregated clusters of lymphocytes with interstitial fibrosis and glandular atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acinar atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and ductal dilatation with no lymphocytic infiltrates:
Incorrect: This finding of glandular atrophy without lymphocytic infiltration is seen in age-related sicca syndrome. In this condition, age-related atrophy of secreting tissue results in decreased tear and saliva flow rates. There is an absence of lymphocytes since it is not caused by an inflammatory process. This patient with parotid gland enlargement, positive Schirmer test, and corneal lesions likely has Sjogren syndrome, a chronic inflammatory process, making this biopsy finding unlikely.
❌ Well-differentiated lesions with prominent keratinization and “pearl-like” structures invading the basement membrane:
Incorrect: This pathologic finding is seen in squamous cell carcinoma. This patient has diffuse, bilateral parotid gland swelling, whereas patients with squamous cell carcinoma typically have nodular enlargement. Moreover, this patient has sicca symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes), which further makes squamous cell carcinoma a less likely diagnosis.
❌ Mixed cellular constitution with myoepithelial cells and chondroid tissue:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas most commonly occur in the parotid gland and normally present as a unilateral, movable mass. In contrast, this patient has bilateral parotid gland swelling and sicca symptoms, making pleomorphic adenoma an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Uniform hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the acinar parenchyma of salivary glands:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of sialadenosis. Sialadenosis is a recurrent, noninflammatory swelling of the salivary glands. It can be seen in certain endocrine disorders (e.g. diabetes mellitus), alcoholism, and malnutrition. This patient’s sicca symptoms and diagnostic findings are suggestive of a different underlying disorder. 
❌ Uncontrolled proliferation of monoclonal B-cells surrounding the ducts:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, which can be seen in patients with chronic, uncontrolled Sjogren syndrome. MALT lymphoma classically presents as a unilateral and nodular mass. In contrast, this patient has bilateral, diffuse enlargement of the parotid glands, which is indicative of another condition.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of a painless mass that emerged on her right forearm several months ago. She has not had any recent trauma to the area. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the hands reveals bilateral swelling and reduced range of motion in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Examination of the patient’s right forearm reveals the following finding:  


Reproduced from: CDC Public Health Image Library  

The nodule is firm and nontender to palpation. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Biopsy of the nodule is performed. Which of the following histological patterns will be most likely present?

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes

questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition that triggers cytokine release by the immune system. The condition often affects the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and metatarsophalangeal joints. In addition, cytokines can travel to other parts of the body, causing extra-articular symptoms.  

In the skin and visceral organs, cytokines lead to the formation of rheumatoid nodules, which are bumps with a central area of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes (a type of macrophage). Palisading means the cells are arranged in parallel layers around the necrotic area. On examination, these nodules are seen as singular or multiple subcutaneous masses that are firm to the touch, non-painful, and distributed around the affected joint.  

Rheumatoid arthritis can also cause carpal tunnel syndrome, since the inflammation causes tendon swelling and nerve compression. Carpal tunnel syndrome can manifest as paresthesia, pain, and numbness in the hand.  

Lastly, cytokines can lead to inflammation of the uvea, which is the layer of tissue beneath the white of the eye or sclera, causing uveitis. Some signs of uveitis include eye pain, conjunctival redness, blurry vision, miosis, and accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber of the eye (hypopyon). If the sclera is involved, it can cause scleritis.  




Option Analysis

✅ Fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proliferation of malignant epithelial cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes skin cancer, with the most common type being basal cell carcinoma (BCC). BCC presents as a waxy, pearly nodule with central crusting or ulceration. However, it would be atypical for BCC, or any other type of skin cancer, to manifest as a firm nodule.
❌ Deposition of calcium salts:
Incorrect: This answer describes calcinosis cutis, which is when calcium is deposited in the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is associated with scleroderma, which can also cause sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and esophageal dysmotility. In contrast, this patient does not have any of these symptoms. 
❌ Palisading granulomas and eosinophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: This histological finding can be seen in the skin nodules of patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Patients with EGPA can also develop allergies, sinusitis, and peripheral neuropathy, none of which are present in this patient.
❌ Needle-shaped positively birefringent crystals:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in the synovial fluid of patients with gout, which causes an inflammatory monoarthritis. The affected joint is generally warm and painful. In contrast, this patient’s nodule is not tender or erythematous.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue and shortness of breath with physical activity. Her symptoms started five months ago. The patient has no past medical history and has not been taking any medications. Family history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis in her mother. The patient’s temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg. An accentuated S2 sound is auscultated over the upper left sternal border. Diffuse skin thickening and tightening is observed. Small calcium deposits are observed at the elbows. Detection of which of the following antibodies will most likely confirm the patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma. Scleroderma starts with injury to endothelial cells that line the interior surface of small blood vessels, causing a non-inflammatory vasculitis. This prompts T-cell migration. The T-cells release cytokines, which attract other immune cells, and activate fibroblasts that produce and deposit collagen. In time, collagen accumulates and forms a highly stable matrix. This buildup of excess connective tissue is termed fibrosis.  

In diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma, extensive fibrosis takes place in both the skin and visceral organs. Thickening and tightening of skin throughout the patient’s body is expected. In the lungs, excess collagen deposition can result in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and pulmonary fibrosis. This presents with dyspnea, restricted inhalation, and coughing. On auscultation, PAH can cause a loud pulmonic component (P2) of the S2 heart sound. In addition, since the right ventricle must pump against an increased afterload, right heart failure will eventually develop (a process known as cor pulmonale).  

Three autoantibodies are often found in patients with scleroderma. Diffuse scleroderma is associated with anti-Scl-70 (also called anti-topoisomerase I) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. Limited scleroderma is more commonly associated with anti-centromere antibodies.   

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticentromere antibodies are associated with limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition present with mild visceral organ involvement and skin findings restricted to the face and distal extremities. In contrast, this patient has diffuse skin thickening and tightening. Moreover, the patient’s dyspnea, accentuated S2 heart sound, and elevated blood pressure all raise concerns for cardiopulmonary involvement.  
❌ Anti-signal recognition particle antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-signal recognition particle (anti-SRP) antibodies are specific for polymyositis. The condition presents with muscle weakness in the absence of skin findings. In contrast, this patient has skin tightening and calcium deposits. Moreover, it would be atypical for polymyositis to cause the cardiopulmonary findings found in this patient.  
✅ Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Anti-Mi-2 antibodies  :
Incorrect: Autoantibodies against the Mi-2 nuclear antigen are specific for dermatomyositis. This condition presents with proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings such as a malar rash, Gottron’s papules, and a shawl sign. However, it would be atypical for dermatomyositis to cause sign tightening or calcium deposition.  
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The patient’s mother has rheumatoid arthritis, which increases the patient’s risk of developing the condition. However, it would be unusual for rheumatoid arthritis to present with skin thickening, tightening, or calcium deposition.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in his right big toe. The toe has been painful, warm, and red for the last several hours. The patient has not had similar symptoms before. He has been consuming 1-2 beers daily for the last 4 years, but recently had a binge-drinking episode 2 nights ago, where he consumed 9 beers. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the right metatarsophalangeal joint. The joint is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Arthrocentesis of the joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,300/mm<sup>3</sup>. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy reveals yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. Which of the following cell types is the primary mediator of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with severe, acute-onset pain, swelling, and erythema of the right big toe after a night of binge-drinking. He most likely has an acute gout attack.  

The inflammation in gout is triggered by precipitation of urate crystals in the joints, which stimulates the production of cytokines by synovial lining cells. The cytokines help recruit leukocytes, such as neutrophils and macrophages. The incoming leukocytes phagocytose the urate crystals, which activates inflammasomes within these cells. This process can be seen in the microscopy image below, wherein monosodium urate crystals can be seen among and within the abundant neutrophils.    

The inflammasomes are involved in the production of active IL-1. IL-1 is a proinflammatory cytokine, which ultimately promotes the accumulation of even more neutrophils and macrophages in the joint. This progressive cascade of inflammation results in an acute arthritis, presenting as severe joint pain, swelling, and erythema.  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Neutrophils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Natural killer cells:
Incorrect: Natural killer cells arise from lymphoid precursor cells and are involved in the detection and destruction of cells that lack MHC-I receptors, such as cells infected with viruses or tumor cells. Natural killer cells are not involved in the pathogenesis of acute gout attacks. 
❌ B-cells:
Incorrect: B-lymphocytes are part of the acquired immune system and are involved in the secretion of monoclonal immunoglobulins (e.g., IgM, IgG), which target specific antigens. These cells are not involved in acute gout attacks. 
❌ T-cells:
Incorrect: T-lymphocytes are part of the acquired immune system. There are various T-cells, whose functions vary depending on the specific type. CD4-positive T-cells initiate the humoral immune response in coordination with B-lymphocytes and also initiate the cellular immune response and cause macrophage stimulation. CD8-positive T-cells are involved in recognition of foreign antigens presented on MHC-I. However, T-lymphocytes are not involved in acute gout attacks. 
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibroblasts are the most common cell type in connective tissue and are involved in the synthesis and organization of the extracellular matrix. These cells are not involved in acute gout attacks.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of pain during sexual intercouse for the last 2 months. She also has difficulty swallowing food, especially bread and crackers, and she needs to chew food for longer periods of time before swallowing it. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 138/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diffuse, nontender enlargement of the parotid glands bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination reveals multiple new dental caries and halitosis. Ophthalmologic examination reveals 20/40 visual acuity in both eyes. Laboratory studies reveal the following findings:
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  10.2 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Platelet count  350,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  3,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  52 mm/h 
 Antinuclear antibodies   Positive 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 Anti-dsDNA  Negative 
 Anti-Ro/La  Positive 
If this patient remains untreated, which of the following is she at increased risk of developing?

choices.text: Gastroesophageal reflux disease due to excess collagen deposition
Blindness due to ophthalmic artery vasculitis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with dyspareunia (painful intercourse) and dysphagia, most likely due to impaired exocrine function resulting in vaginal and oropharyngeal dryness. Taking into account the laboratory finding of positive anti-Ro/La antibodies, she likely has Sjogren syndrome (SS).  

Sjogren syndrome results in 2 classes of clinical features: glandular symptoms and extraglandular symptoms, as seen in the table. SS is commonly associated with an increased risk of corneal ulcers, which may result in vision loss. Another rare, yet serious, complication of SS is malignant transformation of chronically inflamed glands. This transformation results in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, which is a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. MALT lymphomas are characteristically nodular on palpation, as opposed to the diffusely enlarged glands seen in most patients with SS.    



Option Analysis

✅ Malignant transformation of glandular tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gastroesophageal reflux disease due to excess collagen deposition:
Incorrect: Fibrosis of smooth muscle and deposition of excess collagen in the lower esophageal sphincter is the pathogenesis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in CREST syndrome. Although this patient has dysphagia, it is more likely due to an underlying diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome, in which dysphagia occurs secondary to decreased saliva production.
❌ Violaceous periorbital rash:
Incorrect: A violaceous periorbital rash (also termed heliotrope rash) is a rash that occurs on the upper eyelid. It is commonly seen in patients with dermatomyositis, an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy in which autoantibodies attack skeletal muscle and cause profound muscle weakness. In contrast, this patient is not presenting with muscle weakness, making dermatomyositis unlikely. 
❌ Ischemic stroke due to hypercoagulability :
Incorrect: Antiphospholipid syndrome is a condition that increases the risk of thrombosis throughout the body due to procoagulatory antibodies. Although this condition may occur on its own (primary), it often occurs secondary to another disorder (e.g. systemic lupus erythematosus). This patient lacks the clinical findings of SLE (e.g., rash, arthralgia, photosensitivity) and is negative for the specific antibody, anti-dsDNA, commonly found in SLE patients.
❌ Blindness due to ophthalmic artery vasculitis :
Incorrect: Ophthalmic artery vasculitis can occur in giant cell (temporal) arteritis. Although patients with temporal arteritis also have an elevated ESR, this patient lacks the classic symptoms seen in this condition, such as fever, weight loss, unilateral headaches, or jaw claudication.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of low back pain and stiffness for  2 months. The stiffness reaches maximum intensity upon awakening and gradually improves throughout the day with activity. He does not have a history of back trauma or any other past medical history. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows loss of lumbar lordosis and restricted anterior flexion of spine. Babinski sign is negative. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most indicative of this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Gram stain of lumbar synovial fluid with gram negative diplococci

questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy young man’s chronic back pain, morning stiffness that improves with movement, and examination findings of restricted spine flexion and loss of lumbar lordosis are strongly suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (SpA).  

Seronegative SpA refers to a heterogenous group of disorders including ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis, that share some common features, including:  

  •  Sacroiliac joint involvement 
  •  Strong association with HLA B27 
  •  Negative rheumatoid factor (seronegative) 
  •  Inflammation at the site of ligamentous attachment (enthesitis) 
  •  Predominance for male gender 
  •  Onset usually before age 40  
Seronegative SpA usually involves the spine and nearby joints, presenting with inflammatory back pain and sacroiliitis. Other clinical features include peripheral asymmetric arthritis, enthesitis and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Extra-articular symptoms include anterior uveitis, aortic regurgitation (AR), pericarditis and genitourinary symptoms due to sacral spinal cord involvement. Diagnosis requires radiologic evidence of sacroiliitis with one of the aforementioned findings and demonstration of a good response to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).   



Option Analysis

❌ Gram stain of lumbar synovial fluid with gram negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Gram negative diplococci on arthrocentesis is typical of septic arthritis. Affected patients present acutely with a swollen painful, warm joint (most commonly affecting the knee). The lumbar spine is less commonly involved. This patient’s chronic back pain with morning stiffness suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Positive rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor is helpful in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with insidious onset pain, stiffness and swelling of small joints of hands (e.g. metacarpophalangeal joints). Involvement of the axial skeleton is rare; when it occurs, it predominantly affects the cervical spine (as atlantoaxial instability).
✅ Positive HLA B27 :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Mutation in the COL1A1 Gene:
Incorrect: A mutation in the COL1A1 gene results in abnormal production of collagen and the disease osteogenesis imperfecta. This disease tends to present initially in young children or infants with blue sclera, hearing loss, and fractures following minimal trauma. 
❌ Chondrocalcinosis on knee x-ray:
Incorrect: Chondrocalcinosis on knee x-ray is commonly seen in elderly patients with associated joint swelling, stiffness, and knee deformity--reflective of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. Chronic back pain with morning stiffness is unlikely.

questions.text:
