A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of right knee pain that began half-a-year ago and has progressively worsened. The patient previously enjoyed running marathons but had to stop because of the joint pain. Over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen help alleviate the pain. He recently returned from a camping trip in rural Connecticut. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. BMI is 24 kg/m2. No erythema or warmth is noted at the affected joint. Pain and crepitus are elicited on passive flexion and extension of the knee. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Leukocyte Count  7,100/mm3 
 Platelet Count  320,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  12 mm/h 

Which of the following additional physical examination findings will be most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and redness of the uvea
Red erythematous rash with central clearing
Purulent drainage from the knee joint
Morning stiffness that resolves within an hour
Reduced range of motion in the lumbosacral spine

questions.solution:
Arthritis refers to a group of diseases that cause destruction of one or more joints. It can be classified as inflammatory or non-inflammatory.

This patient has osteoarthritis, which occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage. It is a type of non-inflammatory arthritis. Non-inflammatory arthritides usually manifest with asymmetric joint pain that worsens with use, affects weight-bearing joints (e.g., knees, hip), and morning stiffness that lasts for less than an hour. Extra-articular symptoms (e.g., uveitis, pulmonary fibrosis, fatigue) are generally absent in non-inflammatory arthritis.

Inflammatory arthritis is caused by an immune response attacking the joints. It includes conditions with unknown causes, like rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis, or it can be secondary to diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus and Sjogren syndrome. Inflammatory conditions are usually accompanied by joint swelling, symmetric joint pain that improves with use, and prolonged morning stiffness lasting more than one hour. Most of these conditions are also associated with extra-articular symptoms, such as fatigue and malaise.



Option Analysis

❌ Pain and redness of the uvea:
Incorrect: This answer describes uveitis, which is associated with many of the inflammatory arthritides, such as rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis. However, this patient has pain in a single weight-bearing joint and history of joint overuse. As a result the patient likely has osteoarthritis, which is a type of non-inflammatory arthritis.
❌ Red erythematous rash with central clearing:
Incorrect: Patients with Lyme disease, which is most commonly reported in the Northeast and upper Midwestern United States, can have a targetoid rash and migrating arthralgia, meaning that the joint pain spreads from one joint to another. In contrast, this patient’s pain has remained in the right knee joint.
❌ Purulent drainage from the knee joint:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in septic arthritis, which also manifests with joint warmth or erythema. Laboratory testing will show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. In contrast, this patient does not have any of these findings.
✅ Morning stiffness that resolves within an hour:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbosacral spine:
Incorrect: This symptom is seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, a type of inflammatory arthritis. The condition most often affects young males, and it would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to manifest in an older male. Additionally, patients typically have pain in the lumbosacral region, which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and productive cough. The symptoms began one day ago. She reports producing yellowish, non-bloody sputum. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Pulmonary examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung. Examination of the hands reveals swelling and mild deformation of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Abdominal examination is notable for splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   400,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  84 mm/h 

The sputum shows Gram-positive staining. Which of the following additional laboratory findings will most likely be present in the patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has splenomegaly, an ongoing bacterial infection, and a history of rheumatoid arthritis. She most likely has Felty syndrome, which consists of three pathologies: rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. Neutropenia predisposes patients to infections. In addition, patients with Felty syndrome can have thrombocytopenia secondary to splenic sequestration of platelets.

On a systemic level, rheumatoid arthritis can cause anemia of chronic disease. This complication occurs because the liver produces high amounts of hepcidin in response to inflammatory cytokines. Hepcidin decreases serum iron levels by inhibiting its absorption in the intestines and trapping it in macrophages or liver cells.

In addition, rheumatoid arthritis can cause AA amyloidosis, which is a type of amyloidosis that occurs as a reaction to another illness. Rheumatoid arthritis causes the liver to produce serum amyloid A (SAA) protein in high levels. However, if inflammation persists, a small portion of the SAA protein, called AA protein, will separate from SAA and can then deposit in organs as AA amyloid, especially in the kidneys, where it causes organ damage.





Option Analysis

❌ Positive cold-agglutinin test:
Incorrect: Patients with conditions such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection or mononucleosis can have a positive cold-agglutinin test. Pneumonia secondary to Mycoplasma pneumoniae can cause shortness of breath. However, it would not cause excessive sputum production or a gram-positive stain.
❌ Elevated liver enzymes:
Incorrect: Conditions such as hepatitis or biliary tract obstruction can result in elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient’s presentation of splenomegaly and infection in the setting of rheumatoid arthritis raises concerns for Felty syndrome. It would be atypical for Felty syndrome to affect the liver.
❌ Reduced procalcitonin:
Incorrect: Procalcitonin is a marker that can be used to distinguish bacterial from viral pneumonia. This patient has a history of sputum production that is gram-positive, which raises concerns for bacterial pneumonia. As a result, procalcitonin levels would be elevated in this patient.
✅ Reduced neutrophil count:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated anti-dsDNA antibody titers:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). However, this patient’s presentation of splenomegaly and infection in the setting of rheumatoid arthritis raises concerns for Felty syndrome. Neither rheumatoid arthritis nor Felty syndrome would cause elevated anti-dsDNA antibody levels.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of a painless nodule on the back of the left heel. He has had several episodes of joint pain in the last 2 years, involving the toes and knees, that would often resolve after taking ibuprofen. He has not had any fevers, recent joint trauma, or weight loss. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on hydrochlorothiazide and pravastatin. He has been drinking 5-6 beers daily for the last 13 years. He denies tobacco or illicit substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 138/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a nontender, hard, chalky nodule on the left Achilles tendon, as seen in the image below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Similar nodules are present on the left elbow and right external pinna of the ear. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Chronic deposition of monosodium urate in joints

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with hardened nodules on the Achilles tendon and external pinna of the ear; taking into account the history of recurrent joint pains, he likely has tophi formation secondary to chronic gout. Tophaceous gout is characterized by deposition of solid urate followed by chronic inflammation and destructive changes in the nearby connective tissue. Tophi often form on cartilage (e.g. external pinna of the ear), tendons, ligaments, and articular bone. Since tophi form secondary to urate deposition, treatment consists primarily of achieving and maintaining low levels of serum urate. 

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic deposition of monosodium urate in joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of rheumatoid factor antibodies:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with persistent pain in the joints, especially at the hands and wrists, that is typically worse in the morning. Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous lesions formed by necrosis and palisading macrophages and lymphocytes. This patient’s acute episodes of pain in the toes and knees are characteristic of gout attacks and not rheumatoid arthritis. 
❌ Mutation in the HFE gene:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene resulting in uncontrolled iron absorption from the intestines. Patients with hemochromatosis may suffer from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease, which may present similarly to acute gout attacks. However, this patient’s subsequent tophi formation is not seen in hemochromatosis, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Positive human leukocyte antigen-B27 :
Incorrect: Human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B27 positivity is associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, such as psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, inflammatory bowel disease, reactive arthritis (remembered with the mnemonic PAIR). Common findings include arthritis, dactylitis, and enthesitis (inflammation at the insertion of tendon sites). However, none of the aforementioned conditions would result in the tophi formation seen in this patient. 
❌ Positive gram-staining of bone biopsy:
Incorrect: A positive gram-stain of a bone biopsy is indicative of osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis can cause chronic bone pain localized to a single joint. The pain would not be migratory, as seen in this patient. Moreover, osteomyelitis is usually associated with a fever.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recurrent diarrhea and lower abdominal pain of several years duration. The patient has not been previously evaluated for this issue. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medication. Her temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/minute, respirations are 16/minute, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Stool culture is negative for growth. Colonoscopy demonstrates cobblestone mucosa and transmural inflammation. Biopsy of the ileum is shown below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with episodic diarrhea and abdominal pain, with colonoscopy findings of cobblestone mucosa and transmural inflammation, is strongly suggestive of Crohn disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. Biopsy reveals a non-caseating granuloma and lymphoid aggregates, confirming the diagnosis. Of the answer choices listed, only sacroiliitis is associated with this condition.  

Multiple extra-intestinal manifestations are associated with IBD including pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum, episcleritis, uveitis, oral ulcerations and spondyloarthropathy (SpA). IBD-associated SpA usually manifests with sacroiliitis and spondylitis (low back pain with stiffness that improves with movement), peripheral arthritis (most commonly involving the knee), enthesitis (inflammation and tenderness where tendons insert on joint) and dactylitis (sausage fingers). Most of the affected patients are HLA-B27 positive (characteristic of seronegative arthropathy). Treating IBD adequately also improves the symptoms of IBD-associated SpA.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sacroiliitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Esophageal dysmotility:
Incorrect: Esophageal dysmotility is associated with systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), which manifests with puffy taut skin and finger pitting without wrinkles. This condition presents with dysphagia and/or heartburn--diarrhea and abdominal pain are atypical. 
❌ Optic neuritis:
Incorrect: Optic neuritis is strongly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), an inflammatory demyelinating condition which presents with recurrent ocular symptoms (e.g., diplopia, internuclear ophthalmoplegia), numbness, and paresthesias. Gastrointestinal involvement is atypical. Moreover, anterior uveitis, not optic neuritis, is associated with IBD. 
❌ Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:
Incorrect: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca refers to decreased tear production resulting in corneal damage. It is associated with Sjögren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by exocrine gland destruction. Xerostomia (decreased saliva production) is commonly found. Lower gastrointestinal tract involvement, however, is atypical. 
❌ Oral and genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Oral and genital ulcerations in conjunction with iritis and occasional central nervous system involvement  are characteristically found in Behçet syndrome. Abdominal pain and diarrhea can be seen in Behçet syndrome; however, endoscopy shows discrete ulcerations rather than transmural inflammation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning and gradually improve after two-hours of physical activity. In addition, she complains of malaise and decreased appetite for the past several months. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal joints. Ulnar deviation is observed at the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints. Serology testing is notable for elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has elevated cyclic-citrullinated peptide levels, involvement of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints, and constitutional symptoms. She most likely has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joints.  

Cytokines released secondary to joint inflammation can travel to other parts of the body, causing extra-articular symptoms. In the blood vessels, the cytokines can cause wall inflammation and result in various forms of vasculitis, which can make blood vessels more prone to developing atheromatous or fibrofatty plaques. These plaques can lead to cardiovascular conditions such as myocardial infarction and stroke. In fact, cardiovascular disease is the primary cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

 
   

Option Analysis

❌ Spinal cord compression:
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can develop atlantoaxial instability, which can cause acute compression of the spinal cord and/or vertebral arteries during forceful extension of the neck (e.g., orotracheal intubation, trauma). However, spinal cord compression is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis can affect the lungs, causing pleural effusions, pulmonary fibrosis, and other interstitial lung diseases. However, it is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Kidney failure:
Incorrect: Historically, renal failure has been the most common cause of death in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can also cause arthritis, it would be atypical for the condition to manifest with elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody levels.
✅ Cardiovascular disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Septic shock:
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can develop Felty syndrome, a serious disorder characterized by the presence of three conditions: rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. As a result, patients are at increased risk of infection and sepsis. However, sepsis is not the most common cause of mortality in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to pain in her hands as well as fatigue for the past three weeks. The patient has also noticed that her urine appears darker than normal. Medical history is non-contributory, and the patient takes no medication. The patient’s temperature is 37.6 C (99.6 F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/87 mmHg. Physical examination shows erythema and swelling of multiple metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, with tenderness on palpation. Physical examination of her neck and chest is shown below:  


Reproduced from: U.S. National Library of Medicine
 *Dark red spots are biopsy sites  

Laboratory findings are positive for antinuclear antibodies (ANA). Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) based on the clinical features of fatigue, inflammatory arthritis, discoid skin rash, and evidence of nephritic syndrome (hematuria and hypertension).  

 The patient’s laboratory results are also positive for ANA, which is sensitive, but not specific, for SLE and can be found in many other diseases. The next best step in diagnosing this patient's condition is to look for more specific antibodies, such as anti-dsDNA (seen in active disease) and anti-Smith.   




Option Analysis

❌ Anti-histone antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-histone antibodies are present in drug-induced lupus. This patient is currently not taking any medications.  
✅ Anti-dsDNA antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody is a specific antibody seen in rheumatoid arthritis, together with the less specific rheumatoid factor (IgM antibody that targets IgG Fc region). ANA is non-specific and can be positive in many systemic inflammatory conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient’s discoid rash and evidence of nephritic syndrome favors the diagnosis of SLE.   
❌ Anti-SRP antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-SRP (signal recognition particle) is a specific antibody found positive in both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. Other specific antibodies of these conditions include anti-Jo-1 (histidyl-tRNA synthetase), anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2 (helicase). Although ANA antibodies are positive in dermatomyositis and polymyositis, this finding is non-specific and can be seen in many other conditions. In addition, the discoid rash and evidence of nephritic syndrome favor the diagnosis SLE.  
❌ Anti-U1 RNP antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-U1 RNP antibodies (speckled ANA) are seen in mixed connective tissue disease, which includes features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with SLE.  
❌ Anti-DNA topoisomerase-I antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Scl-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase-I antibody) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse scleroderma. The patient lacks the classic signs of diffuse skin involvement and visceral involvement (e.g., pulmonary hypertension and fibrosis, esophageal dysmotility, constrictive pericarditis).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of trouble swallowing for the last 3 months. She now needs to chew food for a longer period of time in order to swallow it properly. She also reports that her eyes have been feeling itchy, with a “gritty” feeling for the same time period. Past medical history is significant for allergic rhinitis and conjunctivitis, which is well-controlled with oral cetirizine as needed. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness of both eyes. There is nontender, diffuse parotid gland enlargement bilaterally. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries and halitosis. Ophthalmologic examination reveals decreased visual acuity in both eyes. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
This middle-aged woman is presenting with xerophthalmia (dry eyes) and xerostomia (dry mouth) for the last 3 months, making Sjogren syndrome the likely diagnosis. Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune condition that commonly affects women 40-60 years of age.  

The cause of Sjogren syndrome is unclear but may be the result of multiple environmental and genetic factors. The majority of patients have autoantibody (anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La) production, which leads to chronic inflammation and damage of the salivary and lacrimal glands. The activated T-cells and B-cells in these glands secrete cytokines, which in turn recruit additional immune cells. This signaling results in the principal finding on pathology, which is lymphocytic infiltrates in salivary and lacrimal glands. The activated immune cells can also affect extraglandular tissues, which may explain the other symptoms (e.g., lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia) associated with the condition.  

Sjogren syndrome can occur independently of other conditions (primary idiopathic Sjogren syndrome) or may occur secondarily to other autoimmune conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis (secondary Sjogren syndrome).    

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-La antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-centromere antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticentromere antibodies are normally found in patients with CREST syndrome. These patients also typically have calcinosis cutis (small white calcium deposits at the extremities), Raynaud phenomenon (vasospasm of extremities), esophageal dysfunction, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasias. While patients with CREST may also have dysphagia, it is secondary to esophageal dysmotility, rather than the decreased saliva production seen in this patient.
❌ Anti-histone antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-histone antibodies are typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus. These patients present with new-onset symptoms of lupus (e.g., fever, polyarthritis, serositis) after starting a new medication. Medications that are classical triggers of this condition include sulfa drugs, hydralazine, and isoniazid. This patient has no history of starting a new medication, and the symptoms are likely due to another diagnosis.  
❌ Anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies, also known as anti-Scl-70 antibodies, are typically present in patients with systemic sclerosis (i.e. scleroderma). Patients with systemic sclerosis present with diffuse thickening of skin, as well as symptoms of dysphagia. Dysphagia in these patients is due to esophageal dysmotility, unlike the patient here, who has dysphagia secondary to xerostomia (dry mouth). 
❌ Anti-Jo-1 antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies and anti-Mi-2 antibodies are classically found in patients with inflammatory myopathies (e.g., dermatomyositis, polymyositis). Both conditions result in proximal muscle weakness, commonly presenting as an inability to rise from a seated position, or weakness during stair climbing. This patient is not presenting with muscle weakness, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Rheumatoid factor antibodies :
Incorrect: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are generally positive for rheumatoid factor on laboratory testing. Rheumatoid arthritis presents with joint pain that is typically worse in the mornings. Although Sjogren syndrome may occur secondarily in patients with RA, this patient presents with no symptoms of joint pain, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in the right knee for the past day. He states the knee is swollen, warm, and red. The patient had a similar episode that occurred in his right ankle last year, which resolved spontaneously without treatment. He also complains of increasing “tiredness” and loss of libido over the last 2 months, but he attributes the symptoms to recent stress at work. The patient has no significant past medical history. His father had a bleeding disorder, but the patient is unaware of the details. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse hyperpigmentation of the skin. The liver is palpated 3.5 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies reveal the following findings:



Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint would most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Large numbers of red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with joint pain, loss of libido, hyperpigmentation, hepatomegaly, and elevated liver enzymes. He likely has underlying hemochromatosis.    

Hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene and results in uncontrolled reabsorption of iron in the intestines. The excess iron deposits in various locations of the body, manifesting as a constellation of symptoms: pituitary deposition leads to hypopituitarism (e.g., hypothyroidism, loss of libido), dermal deposition leads to hyperpigmentation, and hepatic deposition leads to hepatomegaly, hepatocyte dysfunction, and elevated liver enzymes.   

Recurrent joint pain may be caused by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals in joint spaces. Pyrophosphate is a byproduct of adenosine triphosphate (ATP); excess iron in hemochromatosis may interfere with pyrophosphatase, an essential enzyme involved in metabolism of the byproduct. On polarized light microscopy, CPP crystals appear as rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. 


Option Analysis

✅ Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Monosodium urate crystals:
Incorrect: Monosodium urate crystal deposition occurs in acute gout attacks. Although this patient is presenting with gout-like episodes, he also has symptoms suggestive of underlying hemochromatosis (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido). Hemochromatosis would predispose him to another crystal deposition disease.
❌ Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococci that can cause disseminated gonococcal infection, which can present as a migratory, asymmetric polyarthritis. Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection typically present with fever, chills, and dermatitis, which this patient lacks. In addition, this patient is presenting with other signs and symptoms (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido) which disseminated gonococcal infection cannot explain.
❌ Gram-positive cocci forming clusters:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive cocci that can cause septic arthritis and appears as clusters under the microscope. Septic arthritis can present as an acutely swollen, painful joint. However, it also causes a high fever, which the patient in this vignette lacks. In addition, this patient is presenting with other signs and symptoms (e.g., hepatomegaly, hyperpigmentation, loss of libido) which septic arthritis cannot explain.
❌ Large numbers of red blood cells:
Incorrect: A large number of red blood cells may be present in patients with hemarthrosis, which can occur after joint trauma or due to an underlying bleeding disorder. This patient lacks any history of trauma, and although his father has a bleeding disorder, the patient himself has no history of increased bleeding frequency or severity.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of right knee pain, red eyes, and lesions on soles of his feet. The patient states he had a “urinary tract infection” that was treated with antibiotics 3 weeks ago, and his symptoms appeared shortly thereafter. He has multiple sexual partners, and he uses condoms occasionally. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with scant purulent discharge at the lid margins. The right knee is mildly swollen with associated tenderness to palpation. Examination of the soles of feet is demonstrated below. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint shows a leukocyte count of 40,000/mm3 but no organisms on gram-stain or culture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right knee pain and swelling, bilateral conjunctivitis and a history suspicious for chlamydial urethritis, consistent with reactive arthritis (formerly called Reiter syndrome). The erythematous scaly lesions on the soles are keratoderma blennorrhagica, the cutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis.  
Reactive arthritis occurs days to weeks following a urinary tract or gastrointestinal tract infection, and it is thought to be an autoimmune process triggered by molecular mimicry, rather than a pathogen directly infecting the joint. It is highly associated with HLA-B27 haplotype. Causative organisms include Chlamydia, Yersinia, Salmonella, Shigella, and Campylobacter. It usually presents with a triad of asymmetric oligoarthritis (especially involving knee joint), conjunctivitis and urethritis. Other features include enthesitis (inflammation at the tendon or ligament insertion site), dactylitis (sausage digits) and sacroiliitis. Common extra-articular manifestations include oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica (as in this patient) and circinate balanitis (painless erythematous lesions with small, shallow ulcers on the glans penis).  

Option Analysis

❌ Ankylosing spondylitis:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition that presents with low back pain and morning stiffness. Although it is also a seronegative arthropathy, it is not associated with a recent infectious process. 
✅ Reactive arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Psoriatic arthritis:
Incorrect: Psoriatic arthritis is another seronegative arthropathy that occurs in conjunction with psoriatic skin lesions, which are well-defined scaly erythematous plaques on extensor surfaces. An antecedent urinary tract infection and hyperkeratotic vesicles on palms and soles are atypical.
❌ Septic arthritis:
Incorrect: Septic arthritis usually results from inoculation of Staph aureus and presents with fever and severe, focal joint pain. Examination typically shows an erythematous tender swollen joint with associated effusion. Arthrocentesis normally reveals synovial fluid leukocytes >50,000/mm3 and gram positive organisms on gram stain as well as culture. 
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Gout typically presents with acute onset (<12 hours) pain and swelling in the affected joint--usually the great toe. Synovial fluid analysis reveals negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. Vesicular lesions and conjunctivitis are not associated with gout.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms began 7 months ago. She reports that the symptoms are worse in the morning and improve after about two-hours of physical activity. In addition, the patient describes feeling tired in the morning despite getting over eight hours of sleep each night. She has had no sensation of dry eyes. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 140/83 mmHg, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for swelling and pain on passive motion of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. No rash is observed on the patient’s body. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Which of the following antibodies is most specific to her condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by immune destruction of the joints. Patients often present with symmetrical pain that improves with use, morning stiffness lasting more than an hour, and extra-articular symptoms (e.g., fatigue, uveitis). There are three antibodies associated with rheumatoid arthritis: rheumatoid factor, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide, and antinuclear antibodies.  

Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody that targets the constant Fc component of human IgG antibodies. It is not specific and can be present in other conditions ranging from Sjögren syndrome to hepatitis B infection.  

Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is an IgG antibody that targets citrullinated proteins. These are proteins whose arginine residues have been chemically modified to citrulline through a process called citrullination. Anti-CCP antibodies attach to self-proteins, such as vimentin, fibronectin, and collagen. Binding of antibodies to proteins leads to complement activation. The presence of antibodies in rheumatoid arthritis is associated with severe disease and progressive joint damage. Anti-CCP antibodies can be present in the serum up to 10 years before the onset of clinical symptoms. It has a specificity of 96%.   

Lastly, a minority of individuals can develop antinuclear antibodies, which are formed against the normal proteins of a cell’s nucleus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: This patient has symmetric joint pain that improves with movement, which is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Antinuclear antibodies may be found in around one-third patients with the condition. However, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies are more specific for rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid factor can be found in many autoimmune conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus. As a result, it is not highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis.
✅ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-double stranded DNA antibody:
Incorrect: This antibody is found in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can present with a malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis. Although this patient has arthritis, she lacks the other symptoms associated with SLE.  
❌ Anti-Ro antibody:
Incorrect: This antibody is associated with Sjögren syndrome, which can present with dryness of the mouth and eyes due to exocrine gland destruction. However, this patient does not have any of these symptoms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of progressively worsening pain, stiffness, and swelling in her joints. The patient endorses morning stiffness that improves after about two hours. In addition, she reports generalized fatigue despite getting adequate rest each evening. She has tried ibuprofen and acetaminophen for the pain, but neither was effective in improving her symptoms. Social history is notable for a 30-pack-year smoking history. Serology testing is positive for antinuclear and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Which of the following joints will most likely be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joint cartilage. Patients present with symmetrical involvement of three or more joints. The hallmark symptom of rheumatoid arthritis is chronic morning stiffness lasting more than an hour that subsequently improves with use. In the upper extremities, the proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and wrists are frequently affected. In contrast, the first carpometacarpal joint and the distal interphalangeal joints are rarely involved because they contain very little synovium. In the lower extremities, the metatarsophalangeal joints are often affected.

Patients may also exhibit reduced grip strength, reduced range of motion, pain, and swelling. Of note, rheumatoid arthritis does not usually cause redness or warmth, because the inflammation is gradual and chronic. However, it can occasionally present with acute inflammatory signs such as edema, redness, and warmth when there is an acute episode of rheumatoid arthritis, termed a flare.



Option Analysis

❌ Sacroiliac joint:
Incorrect: The sacroiliac joint is frequently affected in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, a chronic inflammatory disease of the axial skeleton. The condition most often affects young males and presents with stiffness in the neck and back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present in a middle-aged woman.
❌ Hip joint:
Incorrect: The hip is a weight-bearing joint that is often affected in patients with osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis causes joint pain that is exacerbated with activity. In contrast, this patient’s history of joint symptoms that improve with activity is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. While rheumatoid arthritis can also affect the hip joint, it tends to occur only in more severe and long-standing cases.
❌ Distal interphalangeal joint:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis can affect the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP). However, this patient’s history of joint pain and stiffness that improves with activity is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. The DIPs are rarely affected in rheumatoid arthritis since they contain very little synovium.
❌ Shoulder joint:
Incorrect: This patient’s history of joint stiffness that improves with activity and constitutional symptoms, in combination with her serology results, are most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. The shoulder joint can be affected in this condition. However, other joints in the body (e.g., metacarpophalangeal joint, proximal interphalangeal joint) are more commonly affected.
✅ Metacarpophalangeal joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of worsening low back pain and stiffness for 2 years. The pain is worse in the morning or after a prolonged period of rest. Review of systems is positive for exertional dyspnea. Recently, he began taking over-the-counter acetaminophen, providing some relief. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates restricted forward flexion of lumbar spine. When the patient is asked to raise his arms above his head and exert a maximal forced expiration followed by a maximal inspiration, the chest expansion observed is1.4 cm (normal 6.5 cm). Chest x-ray is normal. His spinal radiograph is shown below.  


Reproduced from: Radiopedia.org  

Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed in this patient on spirometry?

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) Normal  ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ Normal
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  ↓  ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ ↓
Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↓  Normal

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of chronic back pain, morning stiffness and x-ray findings of fused vertebral bodies is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis (AS). This patient’s exertional dyspnea and finding of restricted chest expansion are highly suspicious of restrictive lung disease (RLD), a known complication of long term AS.  

AS is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that primarily affects spinal and sacroiliac joints. Chronic back pain is the predominant presenting symptom and usually occurs before the age of 40 years. The back pain is classically described as initial morning stiffness that improves with movement and exercise but not with rest. Involvement of thoracic spine often leads to diminished chest wall expansion, resulting in a restrictive lung disease pattern on spirometry (↑FEV1/FVC ratio). In AS, the lung parenchyma is not typically affected, so diffusion of gases across the alveolar capillaries remains intact, resulting in a normal DLCO. Diagnostic findings of AS on radiography includes sacroiliitis (joint space narrowing, sclerosis or erosions), square-shaped vertebral bodies, and fusion of the vertebral bodies (bamboo spine). If plain radiographs are inconclusive, an MRI may be obtained.  

Option Analysis

❌  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are suggestive of a pulmonary embolism or pulmonary hypertension, where the diffusion capacity is diminished due to obstruction by an embolus or arterial intimal hypertrophy, respectively. In these conditions, the lung parenchyma is not affected, resulting in a normal FEV1/FVC.
✅  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ Normal:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: A decreased FEV1/FVC ratio is the hallmark finding of obstructive lung disease. This, together with a decreased DLCO (due to alveolar damage), is suggestive of emphysema. This patient’s progressive low back pain, along with signs of decreased lung expansion, points towards a mechanical cause.
❌   Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC)  Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: An increased FEV1/FVC ratio, in association with decreased DLCO, is characteristic of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Though ankylosing spondylitis can be associated with ILD, chest x-ray in these patients will reveal fibrosis, nodules or parenchymal bands. This patient’s chest x-ray is normal.
❌  Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ratio (FEV1/FVC) Diffusion lung capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) ↓  Normal:
Incorrect: A decreased FEV1/FVC ratio with a normal DLCO is typical of asthma, an obstructive lung disease. In these patients, dyspnea is usually accompanied by cough, wheezing, and tachypnea. Progressive low back pain, along with typical x-ray findings of ankylosing spondylitis, makes a restrictive pattern more likely to be seen on spirometry.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left knee pain and swelling. The patient became concerned when she developed a fever and could not bear weight on her left leg due to pain. Her past medical history includes gout, and her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. The patient was treated for recurrent sexually transmitted infections in her twenties. She denies tobacco or illicit drug use. Her temperature is 38.8 °C (102°F), pulse is 101/minute, respirations are 18/minute, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows an erythematous, swollen, tender right knee with restricted active and passive range of motion. A small abrasion is noted at the inferior aspect of the patella. Arthrocentesis of the left knee performed, and synovial fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 160,000/mm3 with 92% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation  of knee pain with swelling, erythema and tenderness following recent trauma, in combination with synovial fluid findings of elevated leukocyte count with 92% neutrophils, is highly suggestive of septic arthritis.  

Septic arthritis is an infection of a joint space caused by direct inoculation of pathogens into the joint (bite wounds, trauma or iatrogenic), by hematogenous seeding, or rarely via extension from an adjacent tissue into the joint space. These patients present with a painful, warm, tender and erythematous joint with restricted range of motion and an inability to bear weight. The knee is the most commonly affected joint space; followed by the wrist, ankles and hips. The majority of the patients are febrile. Diagnosis is based on synovial fluid analysis and culture which reveals leukocyte counts of 50,000-150,000/mm3 with >80% neutrophils. A positive gram-stain or culture confirms the diagnosis. Plain radiographs, CT, MRI or ultrasound can be obtained when the diagnosis remains unclear or a complication is suspected. Treatment includes source control via emergency joint aspiration or arthroscopy and initiation of empiric antibiotics until culture results are available.  

Option Analysis

❌ Reactive arthritis:
Incorrect: Reactive arthritis is a seronegative arthropathy that occurs days to week after a urinary tract or gastrointestinal tract infection. It is thought to be an autoimmune process triggered by molecular mimicry, rather than a pathogen directly infecting the joint. Synovial fluid is sterile, with leukocyte count <100,000/mm3.
✅ Septic arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Crystal-induced arthritis:
Incorrect: Gout and pseudogout are common crystal-induced arthritis that usually present with acute onset joint pain and swelling. Arthrocentesis shows leukocyte count <100,000/mm3 with birefringent crystals under polarized light. High-grade fever is also atypical.
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the joints of hands and presents with subacute pain, swelling, and morning stiffness lasting for >1 hour. Although septic arthritis is a common complication in joints affected by RA, this patient’s isolated right knee pain is more likely due to septic arthritis secondary to trauma. 
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis is an infection of bone (not joint) and involves the periosteum, medullary cavity, or the cortical bone. It presents with erythema, redness, warmth and swelling on or near the affected bone. Presence of >150,000 leukocytes/mm3 in synovial fluid is atypical.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of shortness of breath. Her symptoms started about a year ago and have progressively worsened. She complains of reduced exercise tolerance and now quickly becomes out of breath while jogging or climbing stairs. She has no chronic cough or excessive mucus production. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis. She has been inconsistent with follow-up due to a lack of insurance. She has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling and deformation of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal and wrist joints. Ulnar deviation is noted at the metacarpophalangeal joints. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function testing yields the following results:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 FEV1  91% of predicted 
 FVC  93% of predicted 
 FEV1/FVC Ratio  85% 

Which of the following best describe the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavities
Pulmonary collagen deposition secondary to chronic inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient has pulmonary fibrosis secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that triggers cytokine release by the immune system. These cytokines can travel throughout the body and manifest with extra-articular symptoms.

In the lungs, cytokines can activate fibroblasts, causing scar tissue deposition, resulting in pulmonary fibrosis. This scar tissue ultimately impairs alveolar gas exchange. As a result, patients can exhibit shortness of breath and reduced exercise tolerance. Physical examination typically reveals crackles, which are thought to be produced by the sudden opening of abnormally closed small airways. Pulmonary function testing will reveal a restrictive pattern wherein the FEV1/FVC ratio exceeds 80%.

The pleural cavities surrounding the lungs can become inflamed as well, causing them to fill up with fluid; this pathology is known as a pleural effusion. It can also impair lung expansion and interfere with gas exchange. Physical examination will reveal reduced breath sounds over the affected area on auscultation, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus.

 Lastly, there is Caplan syndrome, in which the patient has both pneumoconiosis and rheumatoid arthritis. This condition tends to manifest as intrapulmonary nodules.




Option Analysis

❌ Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavities:
Incorrect: This answer describes a pleural effusion. Rheumatoid arthritis can cause inflammation of the pleura and subsequent fluid accumulation. A large pleural effusion can impair normal lung expansion and result in a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing. However, a pleural effusion would not account for the inspiratory crackles.
✅ Pulmonary collagen deposition secondary to chronic inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proliferation of neoplastic lung cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes lung cancer, which can cause unintentional weight loss, coughing, and hemoptysis. Although this patient has a smoking history, she lacks the other symptoms typically associated with lung cancer. 
❌ Hyperplasia of bronchial mucus cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes chronic bronchitis, a condition that can develop in patients with a long smoking history. The condition causes coughing that produces large quantities of sputum. In contrast, this patient has no history of coughing or mucus production.
❌ Eosinophil-mediated lung damage:
Incorrect: Patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) can have eosinophil-mediated lung damage. This damage occurs because the eosinophils release granule proteins that cause tissue destruction, which eventually leads to fibrosis and restrictive lung disease. However, this patient lacks the other symptoms found in EGPA (e.g., allergies, sinusitis).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of pain in both knees. His symptoms worsen with activity and improve with rest and ibuprofen. The patient had previously been an avid runner but had to stop due to the joint pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and a right fibular fracture, which occurred after a biking accident. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination of the affected joints reveals crepitus and mildly reduced range of motion. The remainder of the patient’s physical examination is noncontributory. Knee imaging is ordered, and the results are as follows:




Reproduced from: Radiopedia

Which of the following additional findings, if present, would best support the patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints
Paravertebral ossification of the lumbosacral spine
Subchondral sclerosis at the hip joints
Pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints
Juxta-articular osteoporosis in the proximal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
This patient has osteoarthritis, which occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage and underlying bone. X-rays are used in the diagnosis of the condition. Imaging can reveal the following findings:

 1) Joint space narrowing   

2) Subchondral sclerosis, which manifests as poorly defined areas within the bone that are more radiodense (whiter) than the surrounding bone.  

3) Osteophytes, which often present as an uneven bony protrusion into the joint space.

4) Subchondral cysts, which manifests as a radiolucent (darker) area within the bone.

Figure 1: Radiographic findings in osteoarthritis  


Caption: A) Normal radiograph, B) joint space narrowing in the medial tibiofemoral compartment, C) osteophyte in the joint space, D) subchondral sclerosis, E) subchondral cyst.

Option Analysis

❌ Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which typically affects joints in the hands and causes stiffness/pain that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient has pain in weight-bearing joints that worsens with activity, which is more consistent with osteoarthritis.
❌ Paravertebral ossification of the lumbosacral spine:
Incorrect: This answer describes ankylosing spondylitis, a condition that typically manifests in young males. Patients often report reduced spinal mobility and morning stiffness that improves with activity. In contrast, these symptoms are absent in this patient.
✅ Subchondral sclerosis at the hip joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints:
Incorrect: The “pencil-in-cup” deformity occurs due to periarticular erosions and bone resorption. This finding is classically associated with psoriatic arthritis, but it can also be seen in systemic sclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis. However, this finding would not be seen in patients with osteoarthritis.
❌ Juxta-articular osteoporosis in the proximal interphalangeal joints:
Incorrect: Juxta-articular osteoporosis can be seen in patients with inflammatory arthritis because persistent inflammation induces osteoclast differentiation and impairs osteoblast maturation. The net result is increased bone reabsorption. However, this patient’s history of pain in weight-bearing joints that is exacerbated with activity is more consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for stiffness of both hands that began three months ago. The stiffness does not improve with repeated movement. For the past year, the patient has also had frequent constipation despite consuming a high-fiber diet. In addition, she previously led an active lifestyle and was an avid runner, but she had to stop due to worsening shortness of breath. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F) and blood pressure is 153/82 mmHg. Examination of the patient’s hands reveals the following findings:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional symptoms would most likely be found on this patient’s physical examination?

choices.text: Decreased mouth opening and increased dental caries
Normal appearing skin on chest and abdomen
S3 heart sound most prominent at left lower sternal border

questions.solution:
This patient has diffuse cutaneous systemic scleroderma, which is differentiated by severe visceral organ involvement and diffuse skin involvement.  

In the gastrointestinal tract, patients can have esophageal dysmotility and acid-reflux secondary to replacement of the esophageal sphincter muscle by collagen. The intestines can also be involved, leading to malabsorption and constipation secondary to dysmotility. In the lungs, small blood vessels can be damaged. This causes pulmonary arterial hypertension and pulmonary fibrosis, which presents with dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and coughing. Kidney involvement is also common. The small arteries in the kidneys undergo concentric hypertrophy and this results in ischemia. In some cases the damaged blood vessels trigger thrombosis. This causes capillary blockage and can lead to a form of acute kidney injury called scleroderma renal crisis.    

The skin in patients with scleroderma appears tight, stiff, shiny, and smooth. When it happens on the fingers it is called sclerodactyly. This can cause tapering of the fingertips and finger contractures. On the face, the mouth can become narrowed resulting in microstomia. Microstomia can impair speaking, eating, and brushing teeth. The last factor can predispose patients to dental caries.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metacarpophalangeal joint warmth and tenderness:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with joint pain and stiffness that is worse in the morning and improves with movement. Additionally, it would be atypical for rheumatoid arthritis to cause the fingertip tapering or the taut and shiny skin observed in this patient's hands.  
✅ Decreased mouth opening and increased dental caries:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Normal appearing skin on chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: This would be seen in patients with limited scleroderma. In this condition, there is minimal internal organ involvement, and the skin changes are restricted to the face and distal extremities. In contrast, this patient has dyspnea and constipation, which suggest that internal organs such as the intestines, heart, and lungs may be affected. It would be atypical for this magnitude of internal organ involvement to occur in limited scleroderma.    
❌ Increased anteroposterior chest diameter:
Incorrect: Increased anteroposterior chest diameter may be observed in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), specifically emphysema. COPD can cause dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance. Hypoxia secondary to COPD may cause finger clubbing. However, it would not cause the fingertip tapering seen in this patient.  
❌ S3 heart sound most prominent at left lower sternal border:
Incorrect: A S3 sound may be heard in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of skin stiffness, dyspnea, and constipation are concerning for diffuse scleroderma. Diffuse scleroderma can affect both the skin and visceral organs. It can lead to pulmonary arterial hypertension, heart muscle hypertrophy, and/or restrictive cardiomyopathy. However, it would be atypical for any of these conditions to cause the S3 sound associated with volume overload.

questions.text: A female newborn is undergoing standard assessment shortly after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation. The patient’s 22-year-old mother, G1P1, did not receive prenatal care, has no prior medical history, and takes no medications. The newborn is alert and vocalizing loudly. Apgar scores at 1 and 5 minutes are 8 and 9, respectively. The patient is at the 35th percentile for length and the 40th percentile for weight. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 87/55 mmHg. Physical exam shows annular lesions with central atrophy and raised margins located over the scalp and periorbital area. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in the newborn’s serum?
questions.solution:
This newborn is exhibiting clinical features of neonatal lupus, which is somewhat of a misnomer: neonatal lupus does not refer to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in a neonate. Rather, neonatal lupus is characterized by placental transfer of anti-Ro/SSA antibodies from a mother to her fetus. Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, most commonly associated with Sjogren syndrome (in 80% of patients), are also present in patients with SLE (in 40% of patients). They are also found in 0.5% of the healthy female population.  



Neonatal lupus is characterized by a periorbital or diffuse rash, heart block, and hepatic or hematologic manifestations caused by these auto-antibodies. A rash may be present at birth, but most commonly it is observed a few weeks later, appearing as erythematous annular lesions or arcuate macules with slight central atrophy found mostly around the eyes and scalp. First-, second-, or third-degree heart block may occur, usually between 18 to 24 weeks gestation. Atrioventricular block causes bradycardia with a ventricular rate between 50 and 80 beats per minute, as seen in this patient. A minority of newborns with neonatal lupus will show transient, mild liver enzyme abnormalities and cytopenias.  

Mothers with known anti-Ro/SSA antibody positivity should receive weekly fetal echocardiography from the 18th through 26th weeks of pregnancy to monitor for heart block. Identification of a complete heart block may require pacemaker placement after birth. The rash of neonatal lupus resolves spontaneously after six to eight months, as maternal antibodies are cleared from circulation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) is sensitive for detecting systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Lupus anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Lupus anticoagulant is a pro-thrombotic immunoglobulin that binds to phospholipids and cell surface proteins. It may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but it does not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
❌ Anticardiolipin IgG antibody:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies bind cardiolipin, a macromolecule that makes up 20% of the total lipids in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM) may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but they do not play a role in the development of neonatal lupus.  
✅ Anti-Ro/SSA antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of acid-reflux that began four months ago. The patient has tried ranitidine and pantoprazole; however, her symptoms have remained poorly controlled. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she is currently using an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F) and blood pressure is 118/67 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for skin tightening over the face, hands, and forearms. Several ulcers are observed at the fingertips. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Cholesterol deposition in peripheral blood vessels

questions.solution:
This patient has scleroderma (also termed systemic sclerosis), an autoimmune disorder characterized by the replacement of normal tissue by collagen. Scleroderma most often affects women over 50-years-old.  

The condition can be divided into type subtypes: diffuse cutaneous and limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma. Both cause thickening and tightening of the skin. In addition, both types can cause gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) secondary to replacement of the esophageal sphincter muscles by collagen.    

However, diffuse scleroderma is characterized by severe visceral organ involvement (e.g., renal injury, malabsorption, restrictive cardiomyopathy) and diffuse skin involvement. In contrast, limited scleroderma is characterized by mild visceral organ involvement and affects only skin of the face and distal extremities. Of note, the patient in this vignette most likely has limited scleroderma, as she presents with skin findings localized to the face and distal upper extremities.  

The pathology of this condition is not completely understood. However, it is believed that some individuals have a genetic predisposition to scleroderma, which is triggered by external factors. These triggers include: viral infection by cytomegalovirus and parvovirus B19; exposure to silica dust, organic solvents, vinyl chloride; and medication like cocaine, bleomycin, and pentazocine.    

Option Analysis

✅ Pathological collagen deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Herniation of gastroesophageal junction:
Incorrect: This describes a hiatal hernia, which is a common cause of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that is refractory to medical treatment. Although a hiatal hernia may explain the patient’s GERD, it would not explain the skin tightening or fingertip ulcerations.  
❌ Cholesterol deposition in peripheral blood vessels:
Incorrect: Severe atherosclerosis can reduce blood flow to the extremities and cause tissue necrosis. This may present with ulcers. However, ulcers secondary to atherosclerosis/peripheral artery disease are most often found in the lower extremities. Moreover, atherosclerosis would not explain the skin tightening or treatment-resistant acid-reflux.   
❌ Pathological keratin deposition:
Incorrect: This describes hyperkeratosis, which may be seen in vitamin A deficiency or dermatomyositis. The condition causes skin thickening and discomfort. However, it would be atypical for hyperkeratosis to present with fingertip ulcers or severe acid-reflux.  
❌ Gram-negative bacterial infection:
Incorrect: Infection by gram-negative bacteria, such as Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), can cause gastric acid overproduction. This can result in peptic ulcer formation and potentially contribute to the development of acid-reflux. However, infection by H.pylori or other gram-negative pathogens would not account for the patient's skin changes.

questions.text: A 17-month-old boy is brought to the physician for developmental delay and aggressive behavior. The patient constantly bites his own finger tips, which has forced his parents to put mittens on his hands. He is unable to walk without assistance and has not yet said words like “mama.” His parent states that she has occasionally noticed yellow, sand-like crystals in his diaper when she changes him. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is increased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show an increased level of uric acid. Activity of which of the following enzymes is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
This child is presenting with signs of developmental delay, self-mutilating behaviors, and increased serum uric acid. He most likely has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.    

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is necessary in the purine salvage pathway. Since purine waste-products are no longer able to be recycled for purine regeneration, they are instead metabolized into uric acid. Additionally, since recycling can no longer contribute to purine production, increased de novo purine synthesis is required, resulting in an increase in enzymes involved in purine synthesis, such as phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) synthetase. The combination of increased purine degradation and increased de novo purine synthesis (which results in even more purines being broken down into uric acid) leads to hyperuricemia.  

Symptoms in these patients are secondary to hyperuricemia. Urate crystals, often presenting as yellow-orange sand-like crystals, are often found in the diaper. Urate crystals can also deposit in joints, resulting in gout. Additionally, elevated serum uric acid levels interfere with proper neurologic development, resulting in the characteristic aggressive, self-mutilating behavior seen in these patients.



Option Analysis

✅ Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase:
Incorrect: Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) is deficient in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and therefore, its activity would be decreased in this patient.
❌ Uridine monophosphate synthetase:
Incorrect: Uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthetase is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. A deficiency of UMP synthetase is seen in patients with orotic aciduria, which typically presents as folate/B12 resistant megaloblastic anemia in children with failure to thrive. 
❌ Dihydrofolate reductase :
Incorrect: Dihydrofolate (DHF) reductase is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. DHF reductase is targeted by many pharmacotherapies, such as methotrexate (chemotherapeutic and immunosuppressive drug) and trimethoprim (antibiotic). 
❌ Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II:
Incorrect: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPSII) is involved in pyrimidine base production, not purine base production, and therefore, it would not be affected in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of pain in the right knee for the past day. The patient reports associated joint swelling, warmth, and redness. She says this has happened before in her knees and hips, but those episodes lasted for only a few hours and resolved spontaneously. She also reports feeling fatigued during the past several months, but attributes this to frequently waking up at night to urinate. The patient has also had to strain more than usual when having a bowel movement and frequently takes laxatives to help. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the right knee joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Laboratory studies show the following:



Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy shows rhomboid-shaped, weakly positively birefringent crystals. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints
Tophi formation on cartilage and tendons

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with joint pain, fatigue, polyuria, and constipation, as well as laboratory studies showing hypercalcemia and elevated parathyroid hormone. She most likely has a parathyroid adenoma. Hyperparathyroidism is a significant risk factor for the development of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD), which presents as gout-like joint pain (which explains why CPPD is also called “pseudogout”) that classically affects the knee, although any joint can be affected. The polarized light microscopy findings of this patient's synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis; rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals are characteristic of CPPD. A particularly characteristic finding of chronic CPPD is chondrocalcinosis, which is deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in various cartilage tissues across the body. The menisci of the knee is a common location for cartilage calcification, and the phenomenon is illustrated in the knee radiograph below (white arrows).



Option Analysis

✅ Calcification of cartilage in joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased serum uric acid:
Incorrect: Monosodium urate crystal deposition occurs in acute gout attacks due to increased serum uric acid. Although this patient is presenting with gout-like episodes, the polarized light microscopy findings suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌ Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints:
Incorrect: Osteophyte formation and subchondral sclerosis of joints is a common, pathologic finding of osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis classically presents as pain in weight-bearing joints (e.g., hips, knees) that worsens throughout the day and improves upon rest. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make osteoarthritis unlikely. 
❌ Positive rheumatoid factor antibodies:
Incorrect: Positive rheumatoid factor antibodies can be detected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA classically manifests as pain that is worse in the mornings and improves with joint use. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tophi formation on cartilage and tendons:
Incorrect: Tophi formation occurs in chronic, uncontrolled gout. Chronic deposition of monosodium urate crystals results in tophi formation. Although this patient is presenting with joint pain, the polarized light microscopy findings make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of pain in her hands for several months. The pain is characterized by an intermittent aching in both of the wrists and the bases of the fingers that lasts for hours at a time. The patient also feels warm at night and has not had much of an appetite recently. The patient’s temperature is 37.6 C (99.6 F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild symmetric swelling of the wrists, metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, without tenderness on palpation. There are no skin lesions. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.0 g/dL 
 Platelets  100,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   3,500/mm3 
Further evaluation with urinalysis shows proteinuria and red blood cell casts.    

Which of the following is the most common cause of death in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has fevers, arthralgias, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, with evidence of glomerulonephritis on urinalysis. Together, these findings suggest the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): a systemic, relapsing and remitting autoimmune disease.  

Patients with SLE have overall mortality rates 2-5x higher than the general population. A general high yield fact to remember is that end-stage renal disease, necessitating hemodialysis, is the number one cause of overall morbidity and mortality among individuals with SLE. This is followed by the next two major contributors to mortality: cardiovascular disease and infection.

The cytotoxic agents given to treat lupus as well as the often heavy doses of glucocorticoids used can cause complications like glucocorticoid-induced avascular necrosis of the hips and knees, osteoporosis, and cognitive dysfunction. SLE itself tends to attack the kidneys and slowly, or sometimes in flares, causes decreases in kidney function, eventually leading to kidney failure and the need for dialysis. Once patients are on dialysis (ESRD), they acquire the same mortality risks from dialysis as patients with ESRD from other causes, including life-threatening infection from vascular site access, dangerous electrolyte derangements, and accelerated calcific atherosclerotic disease leading to strokes and heart attacks.  

Option Analysis

❌ Renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Meta-analyses have not shown an association between SLE and higher mortality from malignancies, with the exception of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which is significantly increased among patients with SLE.  
❌ Coronary artery disease:
Incorrect: Ischemic cardiovascular disease is increased in patients with SLE over time. Overall, however, complications from kidney failure cause more deaths.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Although SLE may cause pleuritis and pleural effusions, it does not cause pulmonary fibrosis. Respiratory effects from SLE do not contribute to increased mortality.
❌ Community acquired pneumonia:
Incorrect: In early SLE (within the first decade), the leading causes of death are central nervous system disease, acute renal failure, and infection due to immunosuppression. Overall, however, complications from kidney failure are responsible for the majority of deaths.  
✅ End-stage renal disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of pain and stiffness in fingers and low back for six months. The pain is worse early in the morning and gradually improves over the course of the day. She also has soreness of the heels bilaterally. The patient has been taking acetaminophen with only partial relief. Past medical history includes myocardial infarction with stent placement one year ago. Physical examination shows point tenderness over the bilateral Achilles tendons, as well as effusion and joint line tenderness of 3rd and 4th distal interphalangeal joints of the bilateral hands. The patient’s left thumb is demonstrated below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Which of the following clinical findings is associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces
Well-defined silvery scales and plaques on extensor surfaces
Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surfaces, groin and axilla
Hyperkeratotic, hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck
Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of pain, tenderness, and stiffness of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints (distal arthritis) and spine, along with point tenderness of the Achilles tendon (enthesitis), and nail pitting, is consistent with psoriatic arthritis (PsA).   

PsA is a seronegative chronic inflammatory arthropathy that presents with pain and stiffness of affected joints. It is associated with psoriasis, a chronic inflammatory skin condition that presents as a well-demarcated, silvery, erythematous rash mainly on the extensor surfaces of extremities. Though most patients present with cutaneous symptoms, joint involvement precedes the onset of the rash in about 7% of the cases.  

Psoriatic arthritis is clinically divided into five subtypes:

  •  Asymmetric oligoarticular arthritis: <3 joints are affected, most common presentation 
  •  Symmetric polyarticular arthritis: >5 joints are affected, resembles rheumatoid arthritis 
  •  Spondylitis presentation: sacroiliitis and spondylitis 
  •  Distal arthritis: DIP joints are affected 
  • Arthritis mutilans: deforming and destructive arthritis   
Generally, psoriatic arthritis manifests as a peripheral arthritis worse in the morning and improves with activity, enthesitis (inflammation at the tendon or ligament insertion site), dactylitis (sausage digits) and nail lesions (e.g., nail pitting, onycholysis). Plain radiographs may show the characteristic ‘pencil in cup’ deformity that occurs secondary to erosion and new bone formation within the same joint.  


Retrieved from Radiopedia

Option Analysis

❌ Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces:
Incorrect: Erythematous pruritic papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces are typical of dermatitis herpetiformis which is an autoimmune dermal reaction to dietary gluten observed in patients with celiac disease.
✅ Well-defined silvery scales and plaques on extensor surfaces:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surfaces, groin and axilla:
Incorrect: Pruritic tense bullae on flexural surface, groin and axilla are characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disorder. It has been found in association with dementia, Parkinson disease, and bipolar disorder, but not psoriatic arthritis. 
❌ Hyperkeratotic, hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck:
Incorrect: Hyperkeratotic hyperpigmented plaques on axilla, groin and neck are typical of acanthosis nigricans, which is strongly associated with insulin resistance. It has no association with psoriatic arthritis.   
❌ Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema:
