Incorrect: Dense rope-like bands in skin with strictures and edema occur as a complication of hidradenitis suppurativa, which is a chronic inflammatory disease that results from occlusion of pilosebaceous subunits. It is common in patients with obesity and diabetes or those with a positive family history. An association with arthritis is not well-established.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain and distention. The patient has had several episodes of emesis prior to arrival. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and gallstones treated with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min and blood pressure is 140/83 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen and high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  145 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.7 mmol/L 
 Chloride  102 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  30 mmol/L 

Imaging reveals obstruction of the small intestine. The patient is taken to the operating room, undergoes endotracheal intubation, and surgical adhesiolysis is performed. Three hours later, neurological examination reveals areflexia and impaired sensation in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the neurological defects?
questions.solution:
This patient has cervical spine subluxation, which is when the cervical vertebrae become misaligned secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. If the misalignment is severe, patients can develop spinal cord compression, neurological deficits, and even tetraplegia, which is paralysis of all four limbs and torso.

The condition arises since rheumatoid arthritis affects the C1-C2 joint, also termed the atlantoaxial joint, which is the only synovial joint in the spine. When it is affected, patients can experience neck pain. Sometimes, extension of the neck during endotracheal intubation or trauma can exacerbate the subluxation, leading to acute compression of the spinal cord or vertebral arteries. Since subluxation is not always symptomatic, radiographic studies of the cervical spine are needed for all patients with rheumatoid arthritis scheduled to undergo surgery requiring manipulation of the neck for either anesthesia or the surgical procedure.



Option Analysis

❌ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs when there is rapid correction of serum osmolality (from hyponatremia to normal). Patients with hypernatremia are at increased risk. In contrast, this patient’s preoperative sodium levels are within normal range.
❌ Diabetic neuropathy:
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy can cause sensory (and sometimes motor) loss in the distal extremities. This patient has a history of type II diabetes mellitus. However, the patient’s history of rheumatoid arthritis and recent intubation makes cervical spine subluxation a more likely explanation for her symptoms.
❌ Hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome:
Incorrect: This condition can be seen in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Patients can develop weakness, altered mental status, and coma. However, it would be atypical for this condition to cause areflexia or impaired sensation in the extremities.
✅ Cervical spine subluxation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Guillain-Barre Syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) can cause ascending muscle weakness and loss of reflexes. It occurs after an infection by pathogens such as Campylobacter jejuni. However, this patient has no history of recent infection, and her development of symptoms promptly following surgery makes another etiology more likely.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a three month history of pain and swelling in both wrists. She states that the pain is worse in the morning and is characterized by stiffness that takes approximately one hour to improve. Upon questioning, the patient notes that she had one episode last month where red patches over her cheeks and nose appeared after spending a day at the park with her nephew. She is sexually active with one partner and takes oral contraceptive pills. She drinks approximately four alcoholic beverages per week and does not smoke cigarettes. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows flat, fixed erythema over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. The wrists are visibly swollen bilaterally and are tender on palpation. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.0 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  3,800/mm3 
 Platelet count  160,000/mm3 

Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). She exhibits the classic symptoms of arthralgias, rash, and fever. The malar (butterfly) rash, the most common skin lesion that characterizes acute SLE, was likely triggered by ultraviolet light exposure at the park. Combined with the inflammatory arthritis and laboratory abnormalities (leukopenia), SLE should be suspected.  


SLE is caused by a combination of factors that predispose to an abnormal immune response leading to autoantibody immune complex deposition, inflammation, and end-organ damage. Pathogenesis begins when environmental triggers cause cell damage and apoptosis, exposing nuclear material to the immune system. Genetic susceptibility can lead to poor clearance of these nuclear antigens and to recognition of their moieties as foreign. Dendritic cells present these antigens to B-cells, which then start producing autoimmune antibodies, known as antinuclear antibodies (ANA). These antibodies spread through the bloodstream, forming immune complexes with antigens encountered in the blood, and deposit within various organs.  

These deposited immune complexes activate the complement cascade, leading to enzyme-mediated cell damage, referred to as a type III hypersensitivity reaction. End-organ damage (e.g., rash, nephritis, synovitis) occurs as a result. When complement is activated and used up, serum complement levels (C3 and C4) fall. Another high-yield fact is that because early complement proteins like C1q, C2 and C4 are all involved in removing immune complexes, individuals that lack any of these proteins are predisposed to developing SLE.    

Patients can also develop antibodies to antigens found on hematologic cells, including erythrocytes and leukocytes, and certain molecules, like phospholipids. Binding of these antibodies triggers complement activation via the classical complement pathway, leading to cell lysis and death. This process represents a type II hypersensitivity reaction and can cause hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased erythrocyte sedimentation rate:
Incorrect: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) refers to the speed at which red blood cells drop to the bottom of a test tube. Inflammatory antibodies clump up on the cells and increase the ESR in the case of lupus, though elevated ESR is not specific for lupus. A decreased ESR would not be consistent with this patient’s diagnosis.  
✅ Decreased complement C4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased interleukin-6:
Incorrect: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) causes fever and stimulates the production of acute-phase proteins. IL-6 levels are instead increased in lupus, contributing to B-cell hyperactivity and tissue damage.
❌ Decreased haptoglobin:
Incorrect: Haptoglobin is a protein that binds to free hemoglobin from ruptured blood cells, forming a complex that is removed by the spleen; therefore, haptoglobin levels are low in hemolytic anemia. Lupus can cause hemolytic anemia, but this patient’s hemoglobin level is normal.
❌ Decreased C-reactive protein:
Incorrect: C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase protein whose levels rise in response to inflammation. CRP would generally be elevated in active lupus, but it is not specific for the disease and is not part of the diagnostic criteria for lupus. A decrease in CRP would not be consistent with this patient’s diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. His symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning, and gradually improve with activity. In addition, the patient endorses malaise in spite of getting more than eight-hours of rest each evening. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 147/83 mmHg, and pulse is 71/min. Physical examination reveals the following findings in the right hand:



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Similar findings are also noted in the left hand. Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present on this patient’s physical exam?

choices.text: Silver scale-like plaques on the skin
Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine
Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints
Purulent drainage from the knee joint

questions.solution:
This patient has swan-neck deformities in the hands, malaise, and fever. His presentation is most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition resulting in joint destruction. As rheumatoid arthritis progresses, it can cause several joint deformities. Five notable deformities are:

1) The swan-neck deformity occurs when the distal interphalangeal joint of the affected finger is in flexion, whereas the proximal interphalangeal joint is in hyperextension.    

2) The Boutonniere deformity occurs when the proximal interphalangeal joint is in flexion, and the distal interphalangeal joint is in hyperextension.    

3) Ulnar drift occurs if the metacarpophalangeal joints are severely affected. In this condition, the fingers lean away from the thumb and toward the pinky.    

4) The Z-deformity occurs where the thumb flexes at the metacarpophalangeal joint and hyperextends at the interphalangeal joint. This finding is also termed the “hitchhiker thumb deformity.”   

5) The claw toe deformity occurs where the metatarsophalangeal joint is hyperextended, while the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints are flexed. This causes the affected toes to look like bird claws.


Option Analysis

❌ Silver scale-like plaques on the skin:
Incorrect: Patients with psoriatic arthritis will have both joint pain and skin psoriasis. Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with asymmetrical joint involvement. In contrast, this patient has symmetrical findings. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not typically cause the swan-neck deformity seen in this patient.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in ankylosing spondylitis, a chronic inflammatory disease of the axial skeleton. The condition most often affects young males and presents with stiffness in the neck and back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to either present in an elderly male or to not cause axial skeleton symptoms.
✅ Ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Purulent drainage from the knee joint  :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis can cause fever and purulent drainage. However, this patient’s history of joint pain that improves with movement and presence of swan-neck deformities are more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis would not cause pus accumulation within affected joints.
❌ Inflammation of the conjunctiva:
Incorrect: Patients with reactive migratory arthritis classically present with joint pain, conjunctivitis, and urethritis. Reactive arthritis typically occurs after an infection. In contrast, this patient has no history of recent infection or migrating joint pain.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain that began half-a-year ago. The pain is most prominent in the left knee and right index distal interphalangeal joint. The symptoms worsen with physical activity and improve with rest. The patient is a retired construction worker. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are noncontributory. Examination of the affected knee reveals reduced range of motion. A fine gritting sound is heard on passive flexion and extension of the left knee. No erythema or warmth is noted at the joint. Examination of the patient’s fingers reveals the following:




Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

 A comprehensive musculoskeletal examination is subsequently performed. Which of the following additional joints will most likely reveal abnormal findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has pain in a weight-bearing joint that is exacerbated by activity and improves with rest. These symptoms, in combination with the physical examination finding of a Heberden node at the right index finger, are most consistent with osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage and underlying bone.

Osteoarthritis most often affects weight-bearing joints (e.g., ankle, knee, hip). Osteoarthritis can also affect the hands and manifest with pain in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints due to their high frequency of use. Unlike rheumatoid arthritis, the metacarpophalangeal are rarely affected in osteoarthritis.

Overtime, articular damage will cause a hypertrophic reaction that leads to new bone formation at the joint margins called osteophytes. If the osteophyte manifests as a subcutaneous nodule at the distal interphalangeal joint, it is called a Heberden node (blue arrows). In contrast, if the subcutaneous nodule is at the proximal interphalangeal joint, it is called a Bouchard node (yellow arrow).





Option Analysis

❌ Sacroiliac joint  :
Incorrect: The sacroiliac joint is frequently affected in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. The condition most often affects young men and manifests with limited spinal mobility, as well as morning stiffness that improves with activity. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to manifest in an older male.  
❌ Metacarpophalangeal joint:
Incorrect: The metacarpophalangeal joints are often affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis manifests with symmetrical joint pain and stiffness that worsens with rest and improves with activity. In contrast, this patient’s joint symptoms are asymmetrical and exacerbated by activity.
❌ Wrist joint:
Incorrect: The wrist joints are often affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, which presents with symmetrical joint pain/stiffness that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient’s joint pain is asymmetrical and worsens with activity. Moreover, rheumatoid arthritis would not account for the Heberden nodule (subcutaneous nodule at the distal interphalangeal joint) found at the right index finger.
✅ Hip joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint:
Incorrect: The first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe) is often affected in gout, which is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joint. The condition causes acute-onset pain that subsequently self-resolves within a few days to few weeks. In contrast, gout would not cause pain that persists for several months.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right eye pain and redness. The pain started suddenly, and it is difficult for him to open the right eye in a well lit room. The patient has a history of chronic atraumatic low back pain for which he intermittently takes ibuprofen. Chart review reveals three similar episodes of eye pain requiring emergency department visits; however, the patient failed to follow up with an opthamologist. The patient’s right eye appears injected with associated photophobia.  X-ray of the patient's spine is shown below.  


Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons  

Laboratory analysis demonstrates a C-reactive protein level 26 mg/L (normal <10 mg/L). If left untreated, this patient is at risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of anterior uveitis, including sudden onset eye pain, redness and photophobia.  Additionally, his x-ray findings of vertebral body fusion suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Other extra-articular manifestations of AS include aortic regurgitation (AR) and restrictive lung disease (RLD).  

AS is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that mainly involves spinal and sacroiliac joints, and is associated with multiple extra-articular findings including ocular, pulmonary, cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dermatologic manifestations. The most common extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic regurgitation, restrictive lung disease sans fibrosis, psoriasis, and the inflammatory bowel diseases ulcerative colitis and crohn’s disease.    

In addition, several complications are associated with long term axial AS, including vertebral body fractures, lumbosacral spinal cord compromise,and osteoporosis as a result of abnormal bone metabolism causing loss of trabecular bone in vertebral bodies. It is usually evident within the first 10 years of the disease onset and increases the risk of fragility fractures. No specific guidelines exist regarding the optimal time to start screening for low BMD in patients with AS; however, some authorities recommend screening for low BMD in the first year of diagnosis of AS with continued monitoring every two years, especially in the setting of high disease activity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoporosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Avascular necrosis of femoral head:
Incorrect: Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head results from occlusion of end-arteries supplying the femoral head. Common causes include long-term steroid use, systemic lupus erythematosus, hemoglobinopathies and antiphospholipid syndrome. Ankylosing spondylitis is not associated with avascular necrosis of the femoral head. 
❌ Mitral stenosis:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with scarring of aortic leaflet cusps which can lead to aortic regurgitation. In contrast, mitral valve stenosis is a complication of rheumatic fever, in which the axial skeleton is not involved. 
❌ Felty syndrome:
Incorrect: Felty syndrome is characterized by painful swelling and stiffness of small joints (metacarpophalangeal joints, interphalangeal joints), neutropenia and splenomegaly as a complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. Involvement of thoracic and lumbar spine is unusual.  
❌ Pulmonary hypertension:
Incorrect: Pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery pressure ≥25 mmHg) can occur as a complication of left sided-heart disease, chronic lung disease, and systemic soft tissue diseases like SLE and sarcoidosis. It is not, however, seen in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because of joint pain and stiffness. Her symptoms are worse in the morning and subsequently improve after two-hours of physical activity. Past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she is currently taking metformin. She has a 40-pack-year smoking history and currently smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes daily. The patient lives in rural Maryland and recalls several insect bites while hiking a few weeks ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for swelling and pain on passive motion in the bilateral metacarpophalangeal, wrist, and metatarsophalangeal joints. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints
Degenerative disorder of the joint articular cartilage
Deposition of uric acid in the joint space

questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by autoimmune destruction of the joint cartilage. It presents with symmetrical pain and swelling most frequently affecting the metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP), and metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints.



Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with environmental risk factors, such as infections and smoking, and genetic predisposition, such as female gender and having the HLA-DR1/DR4 alleles. It is hypothesized that environmental risk factors modify normal articular proteins in the synovial joints. The modified proteins are targeted by the immune system, since it fails to recognize them as part of the normal body, causing the proteins to become self-antigens. Antigen presenting cells then pick up the self-antigens and activate CD4+ T-cells. T-helper cells then stimulate nearby B-cells to produce autoantibodies.

T-cells eventually enter the joints and secrete inflammatory cytokines. Likewise, autoantibodies bind to their targets and trigger the complement cascade. The inflammation causes synovial cells to proliferate. This increase in synovial and immune cells creates a pannus, a layer of granulation tissue and inflammatory cells. Over time, cytokines released in the pannus start to break down the articular cartilage, exposing the underlying bones, leading to bone erosion.





Option Analysis

✅ Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection by tick-transmitted spirochete:
Incorrect: This answer describes Lyme disease, which is prevalent in the Northeastern and upper Midwestern United States. The infection can cause a migratory arthritis that spreads from one large joint to another. However, it would be atypical for Lyme disease to affect the small joints of the hands and feet.
❌ Inflammatory damage of the muscles:
Incorrect: This answer describes polymyositis and dermatomyositis. Both conditions can cause proximal muscle weakness and most often affects the shoulders. However, it would be atypical for either condition to cause symmetric arthritis affecting the hands and feet.
❌ Degenerative disorder of the joint articular cartilage:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disorder wherein wear and tear destroys the articular cartilage. It most commonly affects large weight bearing joints and causes pain that worsens with activity. In contrast, this patient has pain that improves with activity.
❌ Deposition of uric acid in the joint space:
Incorrect: Gout is caused by the deposition of uric acid in the joint space. It usually causes acute pain in a single joint, classically the metatarsophalangeal joint of the big toe. In contrast, it would be atypical for gout to cause symmetric arthritis.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. The symptoms are most prominent in the hands. Stiffness is worse in the morning and gradually improves after 1-2 hours of activity. In addition, the patient endorses fatigue and a decreased appetite. She immigrated to the United States from Ireland 5 years ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 147/83 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Imaging of the patient’s hands reveals the following findings:


Reproduced from: Radiopedia  

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints
Deposition of uric acid in the joint space
Overuse of the joint articular cartilage

questions.solution:
This patient's radiograph shows erosion, joint space narrowing, and ulnar deviation most prominent in the metacarpophalangeal joints. Prominent erosion is also seen at the ulnar-carpal joint. These findings, in combination with the patient’s history of joint stiffness that improves with activity and constitutional symptoms, are most consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.   

Rheumatoid arthritis can present with the following imaging findings:  

1) Juxta-articular osteopenia, which is decreased bone density around the affected joint. It is seen as areas of increased transparency on x-ray.  

2) Soft tissue swelling, which is seen as a thick halo around the bone. However, swelling around small joints can be difficult to visualize on x-rays.    

3) Joint space narrowing   

4) Bone erosions, which look as if someone bit into the bone.  

5) Subchondral cysts, which are sacs of hyaluronic acid that form in the subchondral bone, the layer of bone just under the cartilage. On imaging, subchondral cysts look like dark, round, and fairly well-delineated areas inside the bone.

Figure 1: Hand radiograph with annotations

Caption: 1) Juxta-articular osteopenia, 2) bony erosions, 3) joint space narrowing.  



Option Analysis

❌ Bone loss secondary to hypercortisolism:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome, which is characterized by cortisol overproduction, can lead to osteoporosis secondary to decreased bone formation and increased bone absorption. Imaging would reveal increased radiolucency but would not show ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints, joint space narrowing, or bony erosions.
✅ Autoimmune inflammation and destruction of the joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Deposition of uric acid in the joint space:
Incorrect: This answer describes gout, which can cause acute joint pain. However, the condition generally causes monoarthritis. In contrast, it would be atypical for gout to cause the symmetrical joint space narrowing and ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints seen in this radiograph.
❌ Iron overaccumulation within the body:
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis can cause arthritis secondary to iron deposition in the joints. The metacarpophalangeal joints are often affected. Imaging can reveal joint space narrowing and cyst formation. However, ulnar deviation at the metacarpophalangeal joints is atypical for hemochromatosis.
❌ Overuse of the joint articular cartilage:
Incorrect: This answer describes osteoarthritis, which affects large weight-bearing joints and causes pain that is worse with activity. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph shows involvement of the small joints of the hand. Moreover, the patient’s joint symptoms improve with movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a one-week history of joint pains in both of the hands, which he describes as being achy and stiff. The patient also feels fatigued and feverish at times, and he has recently started noticing chest pains when he sneezes. Medical history includes hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and plaque psoriasis. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and etanercept. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows salmon-colored, scaly plaques over both elbows, and mildly tender proximal interphalangeal joints in both hands. Normal heart sounds are heard on auscultation of the heart, and normal breath sounds are heard without egophony or tactile fremitus. The chest is non-tender on palpation. Which of the following will most likely be found in this patient’s blood?
questions.solution:
This patient has the typical symptoms of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE): the abrupt onset fever, arthralgias, and pleuritis. As compared to idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), DILE has a 1:1 male to female prevalence (vs. 1:9), is more likely to occur over 50 years of age (vs. reproductive years), and is less likely to cause a rash (20% vs. 60%). Also, DILE typically does not affect the oral mucosa, CNS, or kidneys.  

DILE is characterized by lupus-like symptoms with positive anti-histone antibodies found in the serum. Drugs metabolized by N-acetylation in the liver are most commonly implicated in DILE, including procainamide, hydralazine, methyldopa, and minocycline; therefore, genetically predisposed individuals who are slow acetylators are at risk for drug-induced lupus. Additional culprits include sulfa drugs and etanercept. These drugs induce antinuclear auto-antibody (anti-histone) formation and cause systemic symptoms at least one month after starting, but most commonly after months or years of exposure. You can remember the drugs that cause DILE by the following mnemonic:  

 


Diagnosis is made through identification of anti-histone antibodies in the blood in the absence of SLE-specific antibodies (anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith). Importantly, up to 80% of patients with SLE may have anti-histone antibodies in addition to SLE-specific antibodies. Removal of the offending agent leads to resolution of symptoms in most cases.  

Option Analysis

❌ Anti-Sm antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-Sm (anti-“Smith”) antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Anti-dsDNA antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-dsDNA antibody is specific for diagnosing systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
✅ Anti-histone antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lupus anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Lupus anticoagulant is a pro-thrombotic immunoglobulin that binds to phospholipids and cell surface proteins. It may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but it does not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Anticardiolipin IgG antibodies:
Incorrect: Anticardiolipin antibodies bind cardiolipin, a macromolecule that makes up 20% of the total lipids in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Anticardiolipin antibodies (IgG or IgM) may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or antiphospholipid syndrome, but they do not play a role in the development of drug-induced lupus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. The symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning, and gradually improve with activity. In addition, the patient reports feeling tired in the morning despite getting more than eight-hours of sleep each night. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild deformation of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The patient is prescribed a disease modifying anti-rheumatic drug. She is warned about its side effects, which include hepatotoxicity, stomatitis, and pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Treatment mainly consists of long-term medications called disease modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), which can be non-biological or biological. Since persistent inflammation in affected joints can cause permanent, irreversible damage, prompt diagnosis and early recognition of active disease are important. DMARDs should be used in all RA patients to maintain control of inflammation and the underlying disease process, with the goal of remission or low disease activity in order to improve disease outcome.  

Most individuals are started on non-biological DMARDs. The most common is methotrexate, a folic acid analog that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. The enzyme participates in tetrahydrofolate synthesis, so its inhibition reduces DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. Its use in the treatment of RA is that it inhibits proliferation of the lymphocytes and other cells responsible for inflammation in the joints. Side effects include pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, stomatitis/mouth ulcers, and nephrotoxicity. Moreover, methotrexate can cause folate deficiency, megaloblastic anemia, and myelosuppression.  


Another DMARD is leflunomide, which reversibly inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, preventing pyrimidine synthesis and suppressing T-cell proliferation. Side effects include hypertension, hepatotoxicity, and teratogenicity. There is also hydroxychloroquine, which is considered to be the safest DMARD and can be used in pregnancy. It increases lysosomal pH in antigen-presenting cells and blocks toll-like receptors on dendritic cells. Side effects include eye toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and excessive coloring of the skin.  


There are also biological DMARDs, which suppress portions of the immune system. Abatacept suppresses T-cells, rituximab suppresses B-cells, while others block specific cytokines. Infliximab and adalimumab are two anti-TNF-alpha monoclonal antibodies. Side effects include predisposition to infection, reactivation of latent tuberculosis, and drug-induced lupus.  

Lastly, short-term medications, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and glucocorticoids, can be used to provide analgesia and symptom relief during an acute flare.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of intracellular NF-KB pathway:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids work via this mechanism and, as a result, suppress multiple inflammatory and immune pathways. Side effects include Cushing syndrome, osteoporosis, and hyperglycemia. However, corticosteroids would not cause the side effects described by the physician.
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of action of fluorouracil. Its side effects include photosensitivity, mucositis, and myelosuppression. However, it would be atypical for fluorouracil to cause hepatotoxicity or pulmonary fibrosis.  
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) work by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase enzymes. NSAIDs can cause kidney injury, gastric ulcers, and increased bleeding risk as side effects. However, NSAIDs would not cause the side effects described by the physician.
✅ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of tumor necrosis factor :
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor (TNFɑ) is a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation. Several fusion proteins and monoclonal antibodies have been developed to target TNFɑ. Side-effects include immunosuppression, reactivation of latent tuberculosis, and drug-induced lupus. However, hepatotoxicity, mucositis, and pulmonary fibrosis are generally not part of this medication class’s side-effect profile.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent knee pain for three months. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is associated with swelling at the knee following strenuous exertion. The pain is not associated with fever, rash or malaise. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 35.3 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a small effusion, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the left knee. A plain x-ray of the left knee joint shows narrowing of the joint space with osteophytes. The patient is advised to follow a weight loss, supervised exercise program, and treatment with diclofenac is initiated to help relieve the associated knee pain. Which of the following steps in the pathway below will be inhibited by the medication used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis of the knee. The patient is started on diclofenac, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAIDs), which inhibits cyclooxygenase via the arachidonic acid pathway.  

During inflammation, cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2, leads to the formation of arachidonic acid–a substrate for cyclooxygenase (COX). Cyclooxygenase exists in two isoforms: COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 remains constitutively active, whereas COX-2 serves as an inducible enzyme. Arachidonic acid gets converted by these enzymes into prostaglandins and leukotrienes.  

NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin and nonselective NSAIDs) inhibit cyclooxygenase isoforms (COX-1 and COX-2);  thereby, decreasing prostaglandin and thromboxane synthesis. Decreased production of prostaglandins results in a reduced inflammatory response.



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 leads to the formation of arachidonic acid, which gets converted into prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Phospholipase A2, is inhibited by corticosteroids.  
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C:
Incorrect: The enzyme that facilitates this conversion-step is lipoxygenase. Zileuton is a selective lipoxygenase inhibitor and prevents the formation of leukotrienes. It is effective in the management of exercise-induced asthma by decreasing airway inflammation. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. These agents are used in the treatment of chronic asthma prophylaxis.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Colchicine exerts its anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting polymerization of beta tubulin into microtubules; thereby, preventing migration and activation of neutrophils.
